    Synthetic RNA Modulators in Drug Discovery

    • Farzad Zamani
      Farzad Zamani
      The Institute of Scientific and Industrial Research, Osaka University, Mihogaoka 8-1, Ibaraki, Osaka 567-0047, Japan
      More by Farzad Zamani
      View Biography
      •  and 
    • Takayoshi Suzuki*
      Takayoshi Suzuki
      The Institute of Scientific and Industrial Research, Osaka University, Mihogaoka 8-1, Ibaraki, Osaka 567-0047, Japan
      *[email protected]
      More by Takayoshi Suzuki
      View Biography
      https://orcid.org/0000-0003-2439-879X
    Cite this: J. Med. Chem. 2021, 64, 11, 7110–7155
    Publication Date (Web):June 1, 2021

    SUBJECTS:

    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    RNAs are involved in an enormous range of cellular processes, including gene regulation, protein synthesis, and cell differentiation, and dysfunctional RNAs are associated with disorders such as cancers, neurodegenerative diseases, and viral infections. Thus, the identification of compounds with the ability to bind RNAs and modulate their functions is an exciting approach for developing next-generation therapies. Numerous RNA-binding agents have been reported over the past decade, but the design of synthetic molecules with selectivity for specific RNA sequences is still in its infancy. In this perspective, we highlight recent advances in targeting RNAs with synthetic molecules, and we discuss the potential value of this approach for the development of innovative therapeutic agents.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Potential drug targets include the approximately 20 000 expressed proteins in human cells, together with their various post-translational modifications (PTMs),(1−3) but among these proteins, only around 10–15% are known to be disease-associated.(4,5) Moreover, many of the disease-related proteins are considered undruggable, in the sense that small molecules cannot bind to them with high specificity or affinity.(6) Thus, there is considerable interest in RNAs as alternative targets. Most of the human genome is transcribed into various classes of RNAs, but protein-coding exons account for less than 2% of the total.(7,8) However, noncoding RNAs (ncRNAs) are involved in a wide range of cellular functions, including RNA splicing and gene regulation.(9−13) Therefore, targeting RNAs, especially ncRNAs, is emerging as a promising strategy to modulate cellular events involved in human diseases, particularly those involving undruggable proteins.(6)
    In this context, small molecule RNA modulators have a number of potential advantages, such as easy tunability of their chemical and biophysical properties, including hydrophobicity, which is important for achieving sufficient cell and tissue permeability. Highly selective binding to secondary or tertiary structures of RNAs is also critical to effectively modulate cellular processes such as protein translation, homeostasis, and localization.(14−18) Several reviews dealing with various aspects of molecular recognition and clinical development of RNA-targeted small molecules have been published.(6,15,19−24) In this perspective, we aim to provide a broad overview of recent developments in synthetic protocols, mechanistic studies, and therapeutic evaluation of synthetic modulators of microRNAs (miRNAs), long ncRNAs (lncRNAs), and mRNAs relevant to human diseases.

    1. Application of Synthetic miRNA Modulators in Drug Discovery

    miRNAs are a family of ncRNAs ∼22 nucleotides in length, generated via processing of longer RNAs by the ribonucleases Drosha and Dicer, which serve as master regulators of miRNA processing (Figure 1). They regulate numerous protein-coding genes by binding to partially paired sequences in mRNAs, which leads either to inhibition of translation or to cleavage of the mRNA in the presence of RNA-induced silencing complex (RISC).(25,26) Misregulation of miRNAs has been linked to the onset and development of many cancers, including glioblastomas and breast, prostate, lung, and pancreatic tumors.(27) Therefore, interfering with miRNA biogenesis could be an effective strategy to induce apoptosis of tumor cells (Figure 1). Antisense oligonucleotides (ASO) are available for inhibiting the function of miRNAs(28) but suffer from limitations such as poor cell permeability, intrinsic off-target impacts, and a poor pharmacokinetic profile.(29) Therefore, alternative methods are needed to modulate miRNAs in cancer biology. In this respect, synthetic miRNA inhibitors are promising candidates.

    1.1. Synthetic Inhibitors of miR-21 Maturation or miR-21 Expression

    Schneekloth and co-workers employed a microarray screening technique to scan a large library of drug-like small molecules for the ability to bind to pre-miR-21 hairpin.(30) In this strategy, molecules were covalently attached to a glass surface by a robotic microarrayer, hybridized with a fluorescently labeled pre-miR-21 hairpin, and imaged. Molecules binding with the RNA induce an increase in fluorescence. On the basis of the screening results, they synthesized a range of carbazole analogues 5 by N-alkylation of carbazoles 1 and epoxide ring-opening reaction with amines 4 (Scheme 1). Various functional groups were introduced to the core structure of 5 to investigate the structure–activity relationship (SAR). The results showed that the dibromocarbazole unit is important for the interaction of small molecules 5 with the RNAs, and the effect of aniline substitution is negligible. The biological activity of the synthesized compounds was evaluated in terms of suppression of the levels of mature miR-21 in cellular models due to inhibition of Dicer-mediated processing of pre-miR-21 hairpin. Differential scanning fluorometry, fluorescence intensity assay, and 2-aminopurine (2-AP)-labeled fluorescence titration assays indicated that compounds 5a and 5b were the most potent inhibitors, and further analysis showed that 5a and 5b exhibited 47% and 59% inhibition of Dicer processing, respectively, at the concentration of 1 μM. It was suggested that binding of these molecules to miR-21 either physically restricted the accessibility of the pre-miRNA to Dicer or resulted in the formation of structurally defective pre-miRNA. This study confirmed that compounds 5 bind efficiently to pre-miR-21 hairpin, but further studies using cell-based assays or animals are needed to assess their potential as chemical probes and/or therapeutic agents.
    miRNAs, especially miR-21, repress important tumor-suppressor proteins such as PDCD4 and phosphatase and tensin homologue (PTEN) in tumor cells, leading to chemoresistance.(31,32) For example, miR-21 promotes cell transformation and metastasis of renal cell carcinoma (RCC) by blocking the expression of PTEN and PDCD4 genes. Deiters’ group used a high-throughput luciferase-based cellular assay to screen a library of small molecules.(33) Their assay employed a paired miRNA-binding site introduced into the 3′-untranslated region (UTR) of the gene of firefly luciferase as a reporter construct, which was installed in HeLa cells. In this assay, down-regulation of miR-21 expression results in a significant increase of the luminescence signal. They identified a small molecule miR-21 expression inhibitor 8 with an azobenzene core, which was synthesized by simple amide formation using propargyl amine 7 (Scheme 2). Compound 8 produced a 500% increase in the luciferase signal intensity compared with a DMSO control at 10 μM concentration. The SAR study revealed that replacing the amide with a sulfonamide group in compound 8 resulted in loss of activity. Other compound 8 derivatives bearing alkyl chains, such as allyl and propyl, instead of the propargyl unit displayed 11–53% lower activities in luciferase reporter assays. The selectivity of 8 for the inhibition of miR-21 expression was also evaluated by using quantitative RT-PCR to determine the levels of intracellular miRNAs, including miR-21, miR-30, and miR-93. The miR-21 expression was selectively reduced by 78%. Further studies are needed to identify the target molecule of this class of inhibitors that regulate the expression of miR-21 in living cells.
    A scaffold-hopping strategy was used to develop 4-benzoylamino-N-(prop-2-yn-1-yl)benzamide derivatives 13 and 18 as oncogenic miR-21 expression inhibitors.(34) As derivatization of 8 is difficult, limiting the ability to explore more effective analogues,(33) Lu’s group aimed to replace the (E)-1,2-diphenylazene moiety in 8 with N-phenylbenzamide. Two different types of benzamide derivatives were synthesized in good to high yields from commercially available 4-nitrobenzoyl chloride 9 and 4-methoxycarbonylbenzoic acid 14 (Scheme 3). The activity of compounds 13 and 18 to inhibit the expression of miR-21 in human cervical epithelioid carcinoma (HeLa) and human glioblastoma U-87 MG cells was examined using flow cytometric and RT-qPCR techniques. Compounds bearing bulky groups on the phenyl ring exhibited higher activity, and 13a showed the highest antitumor efficacy at 10 μM concentration in both cancer lines. It increased apoptosis and upregulated programmed cell death protein 4 (PDCD4), inducing apoptosis in approximately 24% and 13% of HeLa and U-87 MG cells, respectively.
    In another study, Deiters and co-workers synthesized a large number of novel miR-21 inhibitors containing both oxadiazole and triazole rings.(35) Screening with the previously reported high-throughput luciferase-based cell assay(33) identified two 1,2,3-triazolyl-1,2,4-oxadiazoles as miR-21 inhibitors. On the basis of the structure of these hit compounds, novel 1,2,3-triazolyl-1,2,4-oxadiazole derivatives 25 (Scheme 4) were designed and synthesized to examine the SAR. To obtain compounds 25, azidobenzenes 20 and cyanomethylene-functionalized oxadiazoles 24 were synthesized separately from anilines 19 and nitriles 21, respectively, and then coupled (Scheme 4). The SAR study showed that while modification of the phenyl ring in molecules 25 had a major impact on their activity in HeLa-miR-21-Luc cell-based assays, modification of the triazole and oxadiazole units had only minor effects on the miR-21-inhibitory activity of these derivatives. For example, the introduction of an O-propargyl group (R2) on the phenyl ring resulted in a substantial increase in the luciferase signal from RLU = 2.19 to RLU = 12.19 at 10 μM. HeLa-miR-21-Luc cell-based assay identified compound 25a as a promising candidate, and its antitumor activity was evaluated in several cancer cell lines, including RCC, pancreatic carcinoma, glioblastoma, breast carcinoma, and colorectal carcinoma, by means of XTT cell viability assays. Excellent inhibitory activities were observed in all cases, except for RCC, with IC50 values between 3.3 and 6.7 μM. Although the RCC A498 cell line was resistant to 25a (IC50 > 100 μM), it was found that this compound increased the expression of PDCD4 and PTEN, which enhanced the chemosensitivity of RCC cells to the clinically approved chemotherapeutic topotecan. These findings in cellular assays highlight the potential value of the oxadiazole miR-21 inhibitors 25 as chemotherapeutic agents to treat human cancers.
    Deiters’ group also applied their luciferase-based cell assay in a high-throughput screen of a library of small molecules for miR-21 inhibitors and identified a new type of ether-amide heterocyclic compounds as miR-21 inhibitors.(36) They then synthesized a wide range of benzoxazoles 31, benzothiazoles 34, and benzimidazoles 37. Benzazole derivatives 29, 33, and 36 were prepared from commercially available 2-aminophenols 26, 2-aminothiophenols 32, and ortho-phenylenediamines 35, followed by amidation reaction and phenol alkylation to afford the desired products 31, 34, and 37 (Scheme 5). The SAR study revealed that the 5-chlorobenzoxazole and the ether amide linker are crucial for miR-21 maturation-inhibitory activity. Among compounds 31, 34, and 37, compound 31a showed the highest activity in luciferase-based live cell reporter assay, generating a 4.87-fold increase in the luciferase signal at 10 μM. Regarding the mechanism of action, the lead compound 31a was shown to hinder transcription of the miR-21 gene, resulting in considerable reductions of primary and mature miR-21 levels. The miR-21-inhibitory activity of 31a was then evaluated in cervical carcinoma HeLa cells, non-small cell lung carcinoma A549 cells, and ovarian cancer SKOV3 cells, resulting in 57%, 33%, and 31% decreases, respectively, in the levels of mature miR-21.
    Liang et al. reported an efficient protocol to block miRNAs maturation by using small molecule Dicer inhibitors.(37) They employed a fluorescence polarization (FP) assay to identify compounds targeting pre-miR-21. In their assay, the fluorescence polarization of a fluorophore-labeled small molecule is increased upon binding to RNA, due to a reduction in the rate of fluorophore tumbling. This FP-based screening led to the identification of neomycin 45 (Scheme 6) as a pre-miR-21 binding ligand. Compounds 47 were then designed and synthesized via coupling between the N-hydroxyimides 44 as a low-affinity Dicer-inhibiting unit and neomycin 45 as a high-affinity pre-miRNA-binding unit (Scheme 6). Esterification, Mitsunobu reaction, and hydrolysis of 2-(carboxymethyl)-5-hydroxybenzoic acid 38 provided the key intermediate 42, which was treated with O-(4-methoxybenzyl)-hydroxylamine 43 followed by acid-catalyzed deprotection to give imide 44. Azide 46 was prepared separately from neomycin 45 in four steps and coupled with 44 to afford the final bifunctional structure 47. The activity of these bifunctional small molecules to block miR-21 biogenesis by inhibiting pre-miR-21 cleavage was evaluated in vitro. The results indicated that the efficacy was critically dependent on the distance between the two units; a greater distance between these components significantly decreased the miRNAs maturation-inhibitory activity. Compound 47 with the shortest length displayed the highest Dicer-inhibitory potency, showing a 90% reduction of miR-21 formation at 5 μM concentration. To explore the selectivity of the bifunctional molecule 47 for miRNA regulation, the ability to inhibit miR-34a in HEK293T cells was also investigated, and a 40% reduction of miR-34a expression was observed at 5 μM concentration. The results indicate that compound 47 exhibits some degree of selectivity for the inhibition of miR-21 in this cell line. Since neomycin is well-known to target rRNA and influence translation, the effect of compound 47 on translation was also examined by transfecting CHO and HEK293T cell lines with an EGFP reporter and treating them with compound 47. No marked change of EGFP expression and no cytotoxicity were seen at 5 μM concentration of the ligand. These observations suggest that compound 47 has no effect on translation and shows no toxicity.
    Epithelial–mesenchymal transition (EMT), which involves the transformation of epithelial cells to a mesenchymal phenotype, occurs during embryonic development and tissue regeneration. Dysregulation of EMT leads to loss of cellular polarity, cell–cell adhesion, and defects in the cytoskeleton and is associated with a cancer phenotype, as seen in breast tumors.(38) miR-21 is one of the onco-miRNAs regulating the formation of PTEN, which is involved in EMT.(39) Therefore, the inhibition of miR-21 is considered a potential strategy to induce apoptosis of tumor cells. To identify miR-21 inhibitors, Maiti and co-workers designed peptidic aminosugar (PA)-kanamycin derivatives 52 (Scheme 7).(40) They performed PAL–PEG-PS resin-based synthesis of several PA-kanamycin derivatives 52, where the peptide chain was grown on Fmoc–PAL-PEG-PS resin 48 and finally coupled with a kanamycin acid analogue to give the corresponding conjugate 51, which was cleaved from the resin under acidic conditions. The products 52 were screened in a high-throughput displacement assay developed by the same research group,(41) in which a fluorescent conjugated neomycin 45 (F-45) (Scheme 7) was used to screen binding specificity for pre-miR-21. In this assay, binding of F-45 to pre-miR-21 quenches the fluorescence, so displacement of F-45 by other binders is detected as a fluorescence increase. Among the synthesized compounds, analogue 52a (Scheme 7) containing cysteine and phenylalanine showed 140% higher affinity for miR-21 than kanamycin alone. Compound 52a also displayed strong binding affinity (Kd = 4.36 nM) to miR-21 with a relatively low dissociation rate from the target miRNA, causing relatively long-lasting miR-21 inhibition, which is highly desirable to target regulation of miRNA biogenesis with low toxicity in cancer treatment. In cell-based assays, compound 52a significantly down-regulated the mature transcript of miR-21 and increased the expression of both PTEN and PDCD4, cognate targets of miR-21, at 5 μM concentration. Furthermore, compound 52a reversed EMT in MCF-7 breast cancer cells, suggesting potential efficacy of small molecule miR-21 inhibitors for cancer therapy.
    Colorectal cancer (CRC), accounts for about 9% of all cancers worldwide.(42) miR-21 is upregulated in CRC cells and promotes the development of CRC by inducing resistance to the programmed cell death.(43) Cao’s group demonstrated that regorafenib 58, a broad-spectrum kinase inhibitor, directly interacts with pre-miR-21 and inhibits Dicer processing of mature miR-21.(44) Regorafenib 58 was synthesized from commercially available 4-chloropyridine-2-carboxylic acid tert-butyl ester 53 by amide formation followed by aromatic nucleophilic substitution reaction and urea formation (Scheme 8). Several in silico and in vitro analyses were employed to confirm the proposed molecular binding mechanism of regorafenib to pre-miR-21, including RNA-ligand docking, binding energy analysis, fluorescence-based assay, and molecular dynamics simulation. The results indicated that regorafenib binds to the stem region of pre-miR-21 via three hydrogen bonds with three key nucleotide residues, G6, A7, and A13, in the pocket and several hydrophobic interactions, resulting in high affinity for the complex system (Scheme 8bc) (Kd = 0.73 μM). This study offered a new potential approach for anti-CRC chemotherapy based on regorafenib, i.e., inhibiting the Dicer-mediated cleavage of pre-miR-21 to reduce the level of mature miR-21, thereby inducing apoptosis of tumor cells. Further cell-based analyses are needed to evaluate the inhibitory activity of regorafenib in various cancer cell lines.
    Disney et al. used a computational approach known as Inforna to design a non-oligonucleotide-containing structure that would simultaneously recruit RNase L and selectively target pre-miR-21 for enzymatic destruction in cancer cells.(45) Inforna is a selection-based strategy using two-dimensional combinatorial screening (2DCS) of structure–activity relationships through sequencing (StARTS) to detect RNA motif-small molecule interactions. This technique is available to design small molecule binders to Drosha and Dicer processing sites in human miRNAs.(46) The designed heterocyclic ligand 69, consisting of a miR-21 binder 63 and a RNase recruiter, was synthesized from synthetically accessible starting materials via multiple steps, including Cu-catalyzed click reaction (Scheme 9). The binder segment showed high binding affinity for pre-miR-21, with Kd = 0.98 μM. The binding affinity to miR-21 was examined with a Monolith NT.115 microscale thermophoresis instrument using Cy5-labeled model miR-21 molecules, including miR-21 WT (5′-Cy5-GUUGACUGUUGAAUCUCAUGGCAAC-3′) and miR-21 BP (5′-Cy5-GUUGACUGUUGAAUCUCAAUGGUCAAC-3′). Coupling of the binder and recruiter components resulted in enhanced inhibitory activity toward miR-21 in MDA-MB-231 cells, and 69 showed an IC50 value of 0.05 μM. Further analysis revealed that 69 split pre-miR-21 in MDA-MB-231 cells in a substoichiometric manner: 1 mol of 69 cleaved 26 mol of pre-miR-21. Interestingly, while the scaffold 68 with OH at the meta position could efficiently recruit inactive monomeric ribonuclease for dimerization to active nuclease, the meta-OMe substituted compound 68 was completely inactive as a recruiter. Treatment with 50 nM 69 produced an approximately 50% decrease in mature miR-21 levels in MDA-MB-231, A375, and A549 cell lines, due to the enzymatic cleavage of pre-miR-21. To investigate the ability of 69 to prevent metastasis in in vivo assays, a lung nodule metastasis study was performed. MDA-MB-231 breast cancer-derived cells transfected with luciferase were inoculated into female mice having diabetes/severe combined immunodeficiency. After 6 days, the mice were treated with 10 mg/kg q.o.d. of 69. This treatment significantly reduced the number oflung nodules that developed. At the same time, RNA fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) data indicated that the levels of pre-miR-21 and mature miR-21 were decreased by approximately 50%. These finding highlight the potential value of these molecules in cancer therapy.

    1.2. Synthetic Inhibitors of miR-372/373 Maturation

    miR-372 and miR-373 promote tumorigenesis and proliferation in human cells via direct repression of large-tumor suppressor homologue 2 (LATS2), which is associated with cell-cycle regulation.(47,48) A series of new neomycin-based small molecules 74 were prepared by using Cu-catalyzed click reaction between two RNA-binding units, the aminoglycoside neomycin 72 and various natural and artificial nucleobase analogues 73 (Scheme 10).(49) The aim of this synthetic design was to obtain RNA ligands with improved selectivity and affinity compared to each parent compound. Introducing the artificial nucleobases into the ligand structure allows the formation of specific Hoogsteen-type hydrogen bonds with AU base pairs of RNA (Scheme 10).(50) The natural nucleobases in the RNA ligands are also capable of base pairing with unpaired nucleosides of loops, which could increase binding affinity for the target RNA. These bifunctional scaffolds were examined for inhibitory activity toward adenocarcinoma gastric cancer (AGS) cell growth, on the basis of their ability to reduce the levels of miR-372 and miR-373 by blocking Dicer processing of pre-miRNA. Almost all the conjugated compounds exhibited excellent Dicer-inhibitory activity in gastric cancer cells. Compound 74a was the most potent inhibitor, affording almost 100% inhibition with an IC50 value of 2.42 μM. These discoveries show that the multimodal ligands 74 are promising leads for anticancer agents, although further evaluations of their mechanism of action, specificity, and biological performance are needed.
    Duca et al. also prepared various miRNA ligands 81 by coupling artificial nucleobases 79 and aminoglycosides 80 (Scheme 11).(51) The coupling reaction of 2-amino-4-(3-nitrophenyl)thiazole 75 withbenzoyl chloride 76 first afforded 77, and then hydrogenolysis of the nitro group and amide formation reaction gave artificial nucleobase 57. Finally, 1,3-dipolar cycloaddition of 79 with the azide analogue of neomycin (80) afforded ligands 81 in high yields. The Dicer-inhibitory activity of these synthesized compounds was examined in vitro using a fluorescence resonance energy transfer (FRET) method with two target miRNAs (miR-372 and -373). To gain more insight into the SAR of the synthesized ligands, systematic modifications on the artificial nucleobase, linker, and aminoglycoside units were carried out. Increasing the length of the linker or altering the neomycin moiety did not increase the inhibitory activity. However, introduction of a benzoyl group via an amide linkage on the nucleobase increased the potency, and compounds 81a and 81b bearing para-chlorobenzoyl and para-aminobenzoyl groups, respectively, were found to be the most promising inhibitors, which might reflect a more favorable matching of the compounds to the RNA sequence/structure. While compound 81a displayed the best performance toward pre-miR-372 with IC50 values of 0.98 μM (pre-miR-372) and 2.19 μM (pre-miR-373), compound 81b exhibited the highest activity for pre-miR-373 with IC50 values of 1.08 and 1.10 μM for blocking pre-miR-372 and pre-miR-373 cleavage, respectively. Antiproliferative activity of the lead ligands was also assessed in terms of AGS cell growth-inhibitory activity; 81a showed higher activity, reducing cell growth by 50% at 25 μM concentration.
    Duca and co-workers uncovered a polyamine with potential inhibitory activity against in vitro Dicer processing of pre-miR-372 by screening a 640-member chemical library with a cell-free assay.(52) In their assay, pre-miRNA was labeled with fluorescein and dabcyl as fluorophore and quencher at the 3′ and 5′ ends, respectively. Cleavage by Dicer resulted in the appearance of fluorescence. The screening identified a spermine-amidine compound 86 with excellent binding affinity (Kd = 0.15 μM), which suppressed Dicer-mediated cleavage of pre-miR-372 with the IC50 value of 1.06 μM. Compound 86 was synthesized via the coupling reaction of heterocyclic amidine 84 with N-Boc protected spermine 85 in 69% yield (Scheme 12). It markedly inhibited miR-372 biogenesis in gastric cancer stem cells, thereby inhibiting the expansion of tumor stem cells.

    1.3. Synthetic Inhibitors of miR-29a Maturation

    Nakatani’s group discovered xanthone derivatives 92 (Scheme 13), which were expected to bind molecular loops and bulges of pre-miRNAs, as inhibitors of pre-miR-29a Dicer processing.(53) Compounds 92 were prepared by means of Mitsunobu reaction and N-Boc deprotection, starting from commercially available xanthone 87 (Scheme 13). Denaturing urea polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis indicated no direct interaction of 92 with Dicer, and instead it was proposed that inhibitor binds close to a Dicer cleavage site in pre-miR-29a, thereby blocking cleavage. The presence of a bulky methyl group on the aminoalkoxy chain significantly reduced the binding affinity of the ligand (92, R = Me), presumably by hindering its interaction with both loop and double-stranded regions of the miRNAs. Compound 92a was the most potent inhibitor, producing a 41% reduction of mature miR-29a at 200 μM, as determined by Northern blot analysis.

    1.4. Synthetic Inhibitors of miR-1 Expression

    miR-1 is a muscle-specific miRNA with critical roles in heart function; its dysregulation can lead to various coronary artery disorders and heart failure.(54) A wide range of cyclobutene-based small molecules 95 were efficiently synthesized as selective miR-1 expression inhibitors via the photocycloaddition of 2-methoxy-1,4-naphthalenequinone 93 and various aryl acetylenes 94 (Scheme 14).(55) These compounds were initially tested for regulatory activity toward miR-1, miR-214, miR-25, and miR-150 in a luciferase reporter assay similar to that of Deiters’ group.(33) The SAR study revealed that the presence of the 8-hydroxyquinoline ring on the cyclobutene ring is critical for inhibitory activity toward miR-1. Furthermore, the presence of two substituents on the C═C bond of the cyclobutene is important, since compounds 95 with R1 or R2 = H displayed greatly reduced activity. Compound 95a was a selective and potent inhibitor of miR-1 expression, producing an approximately 7-fold increase of the luciferase signal in mouse myoblast C2C12 cells at 5 μM concentration. The results should be helpful for the identification of further small molecule miR-1 probes, but studies to establish their mechanism of action in cells are needed.

    1.5. Synthetic Inhibitors of miR-14 Expression

    aza-Flavanone structures are found in a wide range of biologically active natural products, and Bhadra et al. reported a simple synthesis and antitumor activity of a range of 2-aryl-2,3-dihydroquinolin-4(1H)-ones (aza-flavanones) 98 as selective miR-14 inhibitors.(56) They prepared a series of benzopyranone derivatives 98via one-pot cyclization of ortho-aminoacetophenone 96 and aromatic aldehydes 97 catalyzed by l-proline under mild conditions (Scheme 15). 3-(4,5-Dimethylthiazol-2-yl)-2,5-diphenyltetrazolium bromide (MTT) assay indicated that hit compounds 98a and 98b induced approximately 50% cell death of Drosophila (fruit fly) and human breast cancer MCF-7 cells at the concentration of 4 μM. The presence of bromide or a hydroxyl group on the benzopyranone scaffold was essential for cytotoxic activity. For example, replacing the hydroxyl groups on ligand 98a with either acetoxy or tosyloxy resulted in a significant reduction of miRNA-inhibitory activity. Compounds 98a and 98b at 4 μM reduced the levels of miR-4644 and miR-14 by 80% in luciferase reporter assays, suggesting the potential value of miR-14 inhibitors as therapeutic agents. These synthetically accessible molecules could be a powerful platform for anticancer drug discovery.

    1.6. Synthetic Modulators of miR-122 Expression

    miR-122 is the most abundant liver-specific miRNA, playing roles in hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection and development of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC).(57) Binding sites for miR-122 in the viral genome generally exist close to the 5′ end. In HCV-infected Huh7 cells, inhibition of miR-122 leads to a reduction of RNA levels, causing cell death. However, miR-122 is generally down-regulated in liver cancer cells compared to healthy liver cells, which suggests that upregulation of miR-122 might induce apoptosis in HCC. Deiters’ group synthesized benzamides (100), tetrahydroquinolines (102), and isoquinoline-1,3(2H)-diones (104) as candidate miR-122 regulators (Scheme 16)(58) and used a screening assay based on the psiCHECK-2 reporter plasmid to identify interaction of these molecules with miR-122. The reporter construct incorporates both Renilla luciferase and firefly luciferase, and the targeted miR-122 sequence was installed downstream of the Renilla luciferase gene. Increase or reduction in the Renilla luciferase signal ratio indicated inhibition or activation of miR-122 function, respectively. Benzamide (100) and tetrahydroquinoline (102) derivatives displayed potent inhibitory activity, with compounds 100a and 102a providing 7-fold and 12-fold signal increases, respectively, at 10 μM in Huh7 cells (Scheme 16). However, the isoquinoline-1,3(2H)-dione analogues 104 were almost inactive at 10 μM. The SAR study showed that the presence of halogens on the benzene ring in compounds 100 is essential, as replacement of the halogens with methoxy groups resulted in complete loss of inhibitory activity. Furthermore, introduction of either piperidine or dihydroquinoline instead of the trans-decahydroquinoline motif in compounds 102 led to loss of inhibitory activity. Removal of either the NH2 group or N-methyl groups in ligands 104 also significantly diminished the activity. The miR-122 expression-inhibitory activity of the compounds was also assessed in terms of their direct effect on the expression level of miR-122 in Huh7 cells, measured by quantitative RT PCR. While significant reductions of 72% and 45% in miR-122 levels were observed for 100a and 102a, respectively, at 10 μM, the isoquinoline-1,3(2H)-dione 104a caused an approximately 450% increase in miR-122 expression at 10 μM. The antiviral activity of 100a and 102a was then investigated in a hepatitis C virus/Huh7 cell model, and these compounds caused 48% and 47% reduction in HCV RNA levels, respectively. Since upregulation of miR-122, leading to an increase of caspase-3 activity, induces apoptosis in HCC, 100a and 102a are not expected to be effective against HCC. In contrast, HepG2 cells treated with 104a showed a 20-fold increase in caspase-3 activity. These synthetic miR-122 activators and inhibitors are considered to be candidate chemotherapeutics against HCV infection and liver cancer.

    1.7. Synthetic Inhibitors of miR-182 Expression

    BCL-2 interacting protein 3 (BNIP3) is a bifunctional mitochondrial protein that regulates cell death or survival,(59) and miR-182 is an oncogenic miRNA associated with upregulation of BNIP3 in various types of cancer. A series of kenpaullone derivatives 107 was prepared by acid-catalyzed Fischer indole reaction of 3,4-dihydro-1H-benzo[b]azepine-2,5-dione 105 with various phenylhydrazines 106, as potential BNIP3-targeting miR-182 inhibitors (Scheme 17).(60) The effects of these heterocyclic compounds on the expression of miR-182 and BNIP3 in hypoxic cardiomyocytes were investigated in in vitro assays. The nitro-substituted kenpaullone derivative 107a showed the greatest activity, increasing miR-182 expression 1.6-fold, down-regulating BNIP3, and consequently blocking mitochondrial fission and apoptosis in cardiac cells at 10 μM concentration. In an in vivo ischemia/reperfusion (I/R) heart injury model in mice, compound 107a (50 μM per animal delivered via intravenous injection) improved cardiac functionvia significant down-regulation of BNIP3. Furthermore, the expression of connexin 43, a key protein in intercellular electrical and metabolic coupling, was significantly increased by treatment with 107a. Cardiac function, including end-systolic volume and ejection fraction, was also significantly improved by 107a compared to the control I/R group.

    1.8. Synthetic Inhibitors of miR-18a Maturation by Binding to the miR-17-92 Cluster

    The miR-17-92 cluster is a polycistronic RNA producing seven mature miRNAs: miR-17-3p, miR-17-5p, miR-18a, miR-19a, miR-19b, miR-20a, and miR-92a.(61) Dysregulation of the cluster expression contributes to the invasion and progression of many human cancers via multiple pathways, and suppressing these pathways using small molecules is an exciting potential strategy for cancer treatment.(61) Disney et al. synthesized several benzimidazole derivatives 114via Suzuki coupling, hydrogenation, benzimidazole formation, hydrolysis, and amidation reactions.(62) Compounds 114 were screened using the high-throughput structure–activity relationships through sequencing (HiT-StARTS) system to discover molecules targeting the oncogenic miR-17-92 cluster in prostate cancer cells (Scheme 18). HiT-StARTS is a selection-based technique similar to Inforna/2DCS that explores a compound library by examining the enrichment of selected RNA motifs. Binding affinity to the miR-17-92 cluster was also investigated using a fluorescence labeling technique. Compound 114a was the most selective ligand for Dicer processing sites of miR-18a among the miR-17-92 cluster, and showed high binding affinity (Kd = 32 μM). Furthermore, in vitro Dicer processing experiments indicated that 114a significantly inhibited production of mature miR-18a with an IC50 value of ∼10 μM, leading to activation of serine/threonine protein kinase 4 protein and apoptosis of prostate cancer cells.

    1.9. Synthetic Inhibitors of miR-96 Processing

    Disney’s group reported several benzimidazole-based compounds 122 as potential regulators of oncogenic miR-96. These were designed on the basis of the secondary structure of primary miR-96 (pri-miR-96) hairpin precursor with the aid of a database of RNA motif-small molecule interactions using the Inforna technique.(63) The synthesis of 122 started with deprotection of Fmoc-protected amide resin 115 using 20% piperidine at room temperature followed by amide formation reaction to give 117. Successive N-alkylation, amide formation, N-alkylation, amide formation, cleavage from the resin, and Cu-catalyzed triazole formation then afforded the desired peptoid compounds 122 (Scheme 19). The binding affinity of 122 for miR-96 was measured to evaluate the advantage of the dimeric molecules 122 over monomers 112b and 114a. Compound 122a recognized both the 1 × 1 nt GG and 1 × 1 nt UU loops of the RNAandexhibited the highest binding ability with Kd = 85 nM, approximately 40-fold and 30-fold higher than monomers 112b and 114a, respectively. Binding selectivity of compound 122a to RNAs over DNAs was also assessed, and ligand 122a did not bind to a DNA hairpin (Kd > 50 000 nM). 122a showed the highest activity, selectively reducing miR-96 expression at 50 nM in MDA-MB-231 breast cancer cells and inducing apoptosis without affecting healthy breast cells. It also showed antitumor activity against breast cancer cells in vivo. Nod/SCID mice were injected with MDA-MB-231, and the developed tumors were intraperitoneally treated with 122a (10 mg/kg) every other day for 21 days. Tumor growth was reduced concomitantly with a 50% decrease of pri-miR-96 levels and an increase of FOXO1. A pharmacokinetics analysis of 122a was also carried out. At 48 h after i.p. injection at 2 mg/kg and 7 mg/kg, the plasma levels of 122a were 1.6 and 1.9 μM, respectively, considerably higher than the 50 nM concentration required to trigger apoptosis in vitro.

    1.10. Synthetic Degraders of miR-210

    Exposure to low oxygen levels (hypoxia) induces multiple cellular changes to promote survival and maintain function.(64) Hypoxia-inducible factors (HIFs) are a class of helix-loop-helix-PER-ARNT-SIM proteins and play a role in regulating genes associated with angiogenesis, cell proliferation, metabolism, and apoptosis. miR-210 is a hypoxia-related ncRNA that is upregulated by HIFs in human cells under hypoxia.(64) However, overexpression of miR-210 can have pathological consequences, such as growth of hypoxic cancers and ischemic disorders. Disney and co-workers applied the 2DCS/Inforna approach to identify a class of bioactive ligands displaying selective binding affinity to miR-210.(65) On the basis of the results, they synthesized compounds 127 in five steps, using the same procedure as shown in Scheme 18, starting with 4-(4-methylpiperazin-1-yl)phenylboronic acid 59, followed by hydrogenation, bezimidazole formation, hydrolysis, and amidation with RNase recruiter oligonucleotides 123 (Scheme 20). Among the synthesized scaffolds 124, the longest analogue 124a (n = 3) displayed the most selective binding to pre-miR-210 with Kd = 340 nM in the presence of RNase L, while showing no measurable binding to DNA. The results indicate that the hit compound promotes recruitment of RNase L to pre-miR-210, thereby promoting RNA cleavage. To confirm this idea, the physical interaction of pre-miR-210 and RNase L in cells was examined by means of coimmunoprecipitation. It was found that the RNase L immunoprecipitated fractions displayed high pre-miR-210 enrichment levels only in the presence of the ligand 124a. The inhibitory effect of 124a on miR-210 was also investigated in hypoxic MDA-MB-231 cells (human breast adenocarcinoma), in which 200 nM 124a induced a significant decrease (∼50%) of both pre-miR-210 and mature miR-210 levels, resulting in apoptosis. The results of this study suggest that the 2DCS/Inforna technique can quickly define lead compounds for targeting RNAs, and the activity of these compounds can be enhanced by focusing on and developing molecules that recruit cellular nucleases. Synthetic compounds that target RNAs often bind at nonfunctional binding sites and thus have no effect on the cellular functions of the RNAs. In this regard, the ribonuclease recruitment approach enhances both the selectivity of small molecules to cleave various RNAs, particularly noncoding RNAs, and their cellular activity, regardless of the nonfunctional nature of the binding site.

    1.11. Synthetic Inhibitors of miR-515 Maturation

    Human epidermal growth factor receptor (HER) is a family of tyrosine kinase receptor proteins that facilitates cell growth and differentiation.(66) Overexpression of HERs is tumorigenic, being associated with a wide range of human cancers. miR-515, a member of the ncRNAs, plays a central role in repressing sphingosine kinase 1 (SK1), which synthesizes sphingosine 1-phosphate (S1P), a regulator of HER levels in cancer cells.(67) Disney’s group used Inforna to design a series of dimer scaffolds 126 that would selectively target miR-515 hairpin precursors.(68) The desired dimer products 126 were prepared according to a synthetic route (Scheme 21) similar to that shown in Schemes 18 and 19, starting with Suzuki coupling reaction between 4-(4-methylpiperazin-1-yl)phenylboronic acid 59 and 5-chloro-2-nitroaniline 108, followed by hydrogenation and benzimidazole formation to obtain azide intermediate 114a. Amidation of Rink amide resin 61 followed by several alkylations and amidations and cleavage from the resin afforded alkyne intermediates 125, which then underwent Cu-catalyzed triazole formation reaction with the azide moiety 114a to give 126. The binding affinity of 126 to pri-miR-885, pri-miR-515, tRNA, and DNA was examined. None of the synthesized compounds bound to DNA or tRNA, presumably due to steric hindrance of the substituted benzyl group. Compound 126a (n = 4) displayed the highest selective binding capability for the Drosha site in the pri-miR-515 hairpin, with an excellent Kd value of 0.06 μM. The effect of the synthesized compounds on miR-515 levels and SK1 protein expression in MCF-7 breast cancer cells was examined. As expected, ligand 126a was a potent inhibitor of miR-515 biogenesis and increased the expression of SK1 and the formation of S1P by ∼2.5-fold at 5 μM concentration, resulting in increased HER2 abundance. These discoveries open up a powerful approach to make drug-insensitive cancers vulnerable to therapeutic agents based on their RNA expression profiles.

    1.12. Synthetic Enhancers of RNAi

    RNA interference (RNAi) is one of the major post-transcriptional regulatory processes in human cells, in which miRNA molecules target specific mRNAs to inhibit their translation, and dysregulation causes many cellular disorders.(69) Thus, identification of small molecules that can regulate RNAi in cancer cells has attracted great attention over the past few years.(70) Jin and co-workers screened 2000 FDA-approved scaffolds and natural products using a cell-based assay and identified several enoxacin derivatives 130 as RNAi enhancers.(71) They synthesized these compounds in high yields from commercially available enoxacin 127 by N-Boc protection and amide formation with various amines, followed by N-Boc deprotection (Scheme 22). This chemical biology approach was established to regulate the RNAi pathway by designing small molecules that can enhance RNAi and promote miRNA biogenesis via assisting the interaction of trans-activation-responsive region RNA-binding protein (TRBP) with RNAs. Thus, the effect of enoxacin on the processing mediated by Dicer and TRBP was investigated using an in vitro assay. While enoxacin had no effect on the processing of pre-let-7 or pre-miR-30a by Dicer alone, enoxacin (30 μM) improved the processing of let-7 or pre-miR-30a by Dicer and TRBP together. This observation suggests that enoxacin may target TRBP. In general, TRBP binds to miRNA precursors and accelerates the processing and loading of miRNAs and siRNAs onto RISCs. An RNA-binding assay was also performed to assess the effect of enoxacin on the interaction between TRBP and miRNA precursor. It was found that enoxacin improved the binding affinity of TRBP to miRNA precursors; the Kd was changed from 221 nM under normal conditions to 94 nM in the presence of enoxacin. These analyses strongly indicate that enoxacin facilitates the processing and loading of miRNAs/siRNAs onto RISCs by facilitating the interaction between TRBP and RNAs in human cells. Furthermore, small interfering RNAs (siRNAs) produced from shRNAs suppress the mRNA transcripts of enhanced green fluorescent protein (EGFP) expressed in human embryonic kidney HEK293 cells infected with a lentivirus. Enhancement of RNAi with small molecules increases the formation of siRNA, resulting in a reduction of EGFP-mediated fluorescence. Enoxacin 127 decreased the fluorescence dose-dependently with EC50 ≈ 30 μM, but 130 was ineffective. The carboxylic acid group of enoxacin 127 was concluded to play a key role in the regulatory activity. Furthermore, the presence of bulky groups at the C-3 carbonyl of enoxacin (NH-t-Bu (130a) and NHBn (130b)) significantly decreased the RNAi-enhancing activity. In HEK293 cells, 50 μM enoxacin 127 produced approximately 150% increase and 100% decrease in the mature miR-125a and pri-miR-125a levels, respectively, as determined by quantitative RT-PCR analysis. The results suggest that enoxacin 127 regulates the level of Dicer-mediated processing, rather than Drosha, transforming pri-miR-125a to pre-miR-125a.

    2. Application of Synthetic Small Molecule lncRNA Modulators in Drug Discovery

    lncRNAs are a large family of RNAs, longer than 200 nucleotides in length, present in both nucleus and cytoplasm,(72) and are considered to be involved in gene expression, mRNA translation, and RNA splicing. Dysregulation of lncRNAs is associated with cancer cell proliferation and metastasis, making lncRNAs attractive targets for cancer treatment. However, finding small molecules that interact with lncRNA is challenging compared to the case of the well-studied miRNAs, due in part to the low levels of lncRNA expression in cells.(73)
    Metastasis-associated lung adenocarcinoma transcript 1 (MALAT1) is a lncRNA that functions in the nucleus as a molecular skeleton for ribonucleoprotein complexes.(74,75) MALAT1 has roles in tumor cell proliferation, migration, invasion, and apoptosis and is considered a potential therapeutic target. Hargrove and co-workers reported the synthesis of furamidine derivatives 134 as RNA-binding scaffolds for MALAT1 regulation (Scheme 23).(76) This study was the first example of selectively targeting the MALAT1 triple helix with synthetic small molecules. Considering the well-established binding ability of diphenylfuran-based ligands to a wide range of nucleic acid structures,(77) it was anticipated that 134 would stabilize nontriple helical conformation or bind to the stem loop structure. The diphenylfuran-based compounds 134 were prepared from commercially available substrates via Pd-catalyzed C–H coupling of bromocyanobenzenes 131 with furan 132, followed by amidine formation reaction. The synthesized heterocyclic compounds were screened for binding to the MALAT1 triple helix and stem loop RNAs by means of fluorescence assays. The selectivity of the furamidines was highly dependent on molecular shape; ortho- and meta-substituted structures were predicted to show decreased intramolecular interactions, which might reduce their selectivity and binding to the MALAT1 triple helix. The para-benzylpiperidine furamidine analogue 134a was found to have the highest selectivity for the triple helix over the stem loop constructs, with the triple helix EC50 value of 35.8 nM. This study offers efficient chemical assay methodology for evaluating binding to the MALAT1 triple helix, but further biological evaluations are required to identify selective RNA modulators.
    In another study, an in silico high-throughput screening strategy was utilized to identify two imidazole-based synthetic small molecules as selective ligands for the MALAT1 element of nuclear expression (ENE) triplex (Scheme 24).(78) A minimal 5′-fluorescence-labeled MALAT1 RNA structure was employed to screen a library of approximately 26 000 molecules. To choose the most promising scaffold, a data pipeline consisting of commercial availability, selectivity, and cell-based analysis of the top 28 structures was developed. The Z-score was calculated for each molecule on the basis of the increased fluorescence in the presence of MALAT1 ENE triplex, and those compounds with a Z-score of more than 3 were further studied. Selected compounds were then investigated in an organoid mammary cancer model derived from MMTV-PyMT luminal B tumors in mice at a concentration of 1 μM. Compounds 135 and 136 exhibited the largest reductions in MALAT1 RNA levels, amounting to 54% and 41%, respectively. Furthermore, HEK293T cells treated with these hit compounds showed asimilar morphology to untreated cells, which suggests a lack of toxicity. A preliminary SAR study showed that both the benzimidazole unit and the OMe group on the benzene ring of 135 are important for potency. FRET and isothermal titration calorimetry experiments confirmed that 135 and 136 bind directly to the ENE triplex with Kd values in the micromolar range. Molecular docking analysis predicted that compound 135 binds within the major groove of the triplex via van der Waals interactions with the two U-rich strands (U37 0U38 U39 and U10 U11 C12) over the 3′ A-rich tail (Scheme 24b). In contrast, 136 displayed a different binding mode, mostly involving hydrogen bonds with A67 and U47, and the docking sites are spread across the narrow minor groove surface of the MALAT1 ENE triplex (Scheme 24b). This study provides a useful chemical strategy for developing potential anticancer agents based on the function of MALAT1.
    Alkylglycerone phosphate synthase (AGPS) catalyzes the synthesis of ether lipids, which are related to cancer development in humans.(79) Upregulation of AGPS increases the invasive potential of many types of tumor cells, leading to increased cancer cell growth and metastasis. Qian and Zhu reported the computer-aided design and synthesis of a nitrogen-based heterocyclic compound 141 as an AGPS inhibitor, which may modulate the expression of AGPS-regulated lncRNAs.(80) Their virtual screening approach was based on a combined 2D/3D examination of the interaction of the nitrogenous heterocyclic compounds with amino acid residues of AGPS. The hit imidazotriazine compound 141 was synthesized by reaction of an imidazolamide 137 with aminoisocyanate 139, followed by amide formation reaction, as shown in Scheme 25. Notably, compound 141 showed high antiproliferative activity in U251 glioma and MCF-7 breast cancer cells at 50 μM, simultaneously decreasing the expression of tumor-related oncogenes and increasing the expression of apoptosis-associated genes, including lncRNAs, GAS5, CASC2, ANCR, and MEG3, which may be regulated by AGPS. Western blotting analysis showed that 141 significantly inhibited AGPS expression in U251 glioma and MCF-7 cells. A significant reduction in the U251 and MCF-7 cell populations in the G1 phase and an increase in the number of cells in the G2/M phase were observed after 72 h in the presence of 50 μM 141.
    HOX transcript antisense intergenic RNA (HOTAIR) is one of the widely studied long noncoding RNAs that plays a fundamental role in chromatin reprogramming, as well as transcriptional and post-transcriptional modulations.(81) It is well established that HOTAIR is overexpressed in various types of human cancers, such as gastric cancer, esophageal cancer, breast cancer, and lung cancer,(82) and high expression levels of HOTAIR are associated with a considerably worse prognosis. Mechanistically, the 5′ domain of HOTAIR appears to be mainly responsible for tumor development and progression in cancer cells through recruiting and binding to chromatin-modifying protein enhancer of zeste homologue 2 (EZH2) to silence a target gene, nemo-like kinase (NLK).(83) Thus, there is great interest in the development of small molecules to selectively block HOTAIR activity. Kang and co-workers established a structure-based strategy, using an in silico screening of the PubChem library to discover a lead molecule that selectively inhibits the HOTAIR/EZH2 interaction.(84) 3D RNA modeling of the 212–300 nt region in the 5′ domain of HOTAIR attached to EZH2 was performed using the MC-Fold and MC-Sym programs. Among 2000 virtually screened compounds, ADQ 142 (Scheme 26) displayed the greatest binding affinity for HOTAIR. This compound also increased NLK luciferase activity by 2–2.5 fold in four cancer cell lines: MDA-MB-231 breast cancer cells, U87, U87-EGFRvIII, and LN229 glioma cells. RNA immunoprecipitation experiments using 142 in U87 and MDA-MB-231 cells showed significant reductions of HOTAIR-binding EZH2 levels, as determined by agarose gel electrophoresis and qPCR. These observations indicate that 142 effectively inhibits the formation of the HOTAIR/EZH2 complex. More importantly, the binding affinity of 142 to other lncRNAs, including MALAT1, KCNQ1OT1, HOTAIRM1, XIST, and HOXA11, to polycomb repressive complex 2 containing EZH2 was also investigated. In these cases, 142 caused no noticeable reduction of the lncRNA signals, indicating that it has high selectivity for the HOTAIR/EZH2 complex. Molecular docking and conformational analysis indicated that the 36G46A microdomain of HOTAIR forms a specific binding pocket in which the nitrobenzene units of 142 form π–π stacking with the 36G and 46A sequences. The SAR study revealed that the nitro substitution on the quinoxaline unit was essential for the inhibitory activity of 142, as introducing dimethyl and chloro groups into the benzene ring led to loss of inhibitory activity. The reason for this may be that the nitro substitution improves π–π stacking between ADQ and HOTAIR due to its greater conjugation effect compared with the other substituents. Antitumor activity of 142 was investigated in vivo using a mouse MDA-MB-231 orthotopic tumor transplantation model. Injection of MDA-MB-231 cells into the mice led to the formation of large metastatic nodules in the lungs. Treatment of the inoculated mice with 15 mg/kg ADQ 142 every 2 days for 21 days significantly decreased the number and volume of metastatic nodules, suggesting that 142 effectively suppressed HOTAIR-mediated tumor metastasis. Furthermore, a considerable increase of NLK-positive cells in the treated samples was detected by immunohistochemical staining, supporting the idea that ADQ 142 inhibits the HOTAIR/EZH2 interaction, thereby increasing the expression of NLK.
    Application of synthetic lncRNA inhibitors in cancer biology is still at a very early stage, but they have potentials for treating a wide range of human diseases including cancers.

    3. Application of Synthetic Small Molecule mRNA Modulators in Drug Discovery

    Small-molecule-based RNA ligands that inhibit a specific step in the gene expression pathway are versatile tools in cell biology, as well as candidate anticancer agents.(85) For example, inhibition of splicing of mRNA precursors (pre-mRNAs), a key step in eukaryotic gene expression in which introns are removed from nascent transcripts, is a potentially interesting approach to repress tumorigenesis in human cells. In this section, we will discuss several approaches to mRNA inhibition.

    3.1. Synthetic Inhibitors of mRNA Translation Processing

    RNA G-quadruplexes are noncanonical secondary structures of RNA generated from cyclic planar ordering of four connected guanine units (G-quartets).(86) These structures participate in critical cellular events such as translational regulation, transcription ending, pre-mRNA splicing, and mRNA processing. Thus, synthetic small molecules targeting RNA G-quadruplex are candidate anticancer agents. Uesugi and co-workers identified 149 as an RNA G-quadruplex stabilizer that inhibits mRNA translation, using an in vitro screening strategy based on quantitative real-time PCR evaluation of complementary DNA (cDNA) production.(87) It is well-known that RNA G-quadruplex structures are thermodynamically stable and suppress the cDNA production by reverse transcriptase, so RNA G-quadruplex stabilizers are expected to decrease cDNA production in their assay system. The hit compound 149 was efficiently synthesized from commercially available 2-acetylfuran 143via Knoevenagel reaction, thiophene ring formation, pyrimidone formation, followed by intermolecular N-alkylation-based cyclization of two pyrimidone moieties (Scheme 27). Telomeric repeat-containing RNA (TERRA) was chosen as a well-characterized RNA G-quadruplex substrate to start the biological analyses. The binding ability was first assessed by size exclusion chromatography, in which 149 showed selective binding to TERRA with the Kd value of 5.9 μM and did not bind to other RNA or DNA structures. To test the hypothesis that stabilization of the RNA G-quadruplex by 149 would suppress mRNA translation in human breast tumor cells, followed by a decrease of NRAS proto-oncogene expression, the effect of 149 on the NRAS expression in human breast cancer MCF-7 cells was investigated. Upon treatment of the tumor cells with 149 at the concentration of 20 μM, the NRAS expression level was significantly decreased, as determined by Western blot analysis. This result confirms that 149 stabilizes RNA G-quadruplex structure in NRAS mRNA in cancer cells.
    Programmed −1 ribosomal frame-shifting (−1PRF) is a recoding process that produces two different proteins from a single transcript by redirecting mRNA translation and is used by viruses such as coronaviruses to guarantee correct stoichiometry of protein complexes required for their propagation.(88) In eukaryotic cells, −1PRF is controlled by an mRNA pseudoknot, in which the ribosome restarts protein decoding by uncoiling the RNA pseudoknot structure to begin the −1 frame translation. A pseudoknot is one of the most common stable three-dimensional folded structures of RNAs and is generally formed by stem-loop base pairing of a single-stranded RNA.(89) Nakatani’s group reported a class of naphthyridine-based structures 158 as mRNA modifiers (Scheme 28).(90) Compounds 158 consist of a N-alkoxycarbonyl-1,8-naphthyridine scaffold bearing hydrogen-bonding sites that can bind to guanine units in a CGG/CGG sequence of mRNA (Scheme 28). These dimers (155) also displayed some binding ability to the corresponding sequence in DNA. These naphthyridine carbamate tetramers (158) were synthesized from 3,3′-iminodipropionitrile 150 through ester formation, N-Boc protection, hydrolysis, amidation, and reductive aminoalkylation reactions. Initially, three pseudoknot sequences were prepared by mutation of a mouse mammary tumor virus (MMTV) pseudoknot (VPK); they were designated as F-VPK (mutating G2 to C2 and C18 to G18), M1-VPK (mutating C3 to G3), and M2-VPK (mutating C5 to G5 and C19 to G19). The ability of the synthesized heterocycles 158 to induce the −1PRF process was analyzed by means of in vitro assays measuring the protein products generated from the mRNAs encoding Renilla luciferase and truncated firefly luciferase. Western blot results indicated that ligand 158a (n = 8) was the most effective regulator to increase the frame-shifting efficiency (FE) of −1PRF, and an increase of FE from 13% to 20% was observed for the M1-VPK sequence in the presence of 10 μM 158a. In addition, FE of the M2-VPK sequence was significantly improved from 15% to 27% in the presence of 10 μM 158a. On the other hand, the amount of protein products obtained from mRNAs containing the F-VPK was reduced from 29% to 21%, reflecting the inhibitory effect of 158a on translation. The effect of compound 158a on frame-shifting in human cells was next investigated. Upon treatment of HeLa cells with different concentrations of 158a, FE for the M1- and M2-VPK sequences increased from 0.35% to 3.19% (9.1-fold increase) and from 0.32% to 1.70% (5.3-fold increase), respectively, in the presence of 0.3 μM 158a. In contrast, since the F-VPK sequence has a more stable pseudoknot structure than the others, the FE was only slightly increased (1.5-fold) at a higher concentration of 158a (>0.1 μM). This work offers a unique approach to regulate ribosome reading frame selection using synthetically accessible ligands and might find applications in drug discovery.
    Overexpression of the presynaptic protein α-synuclein (SNCA) is associated with severe neurodegenerative diseases, such as Parkinson’s disease, dementia, and Alzheimer’s disease.(91) α-Synuclein is difficult to target due to the absence of drug-binding pockets, so decreasing its expression by targeting the mRNA is a possible approach for therapeutic purposes. SNCA mRNA has an iron-responsive element (IRE) in the 5′ UTR, which is involved in the translation process. Disney and co-workers reported sequence-based design of several synucleozid derivatives (Scheme 29) that selectively target the IRE structure of SNCA mRNA and consequently inhibit α-synuclein expression.(92) Synucleozid analogues 165, 169, and 172 were synthesized via the reaction of either 4-hydroxybenzaldehyde 159 or 4-aminobenzaldehyde 169 with 4-fluorobenzonitrile 160 to form adducts 161 and 170, respectively, followed by condensation reaction with 3,4-diaminobenzonitrile 166 to give 167 and 171 (Scheme 29). Compound 161 was treated with 4-methyl-3-nitrobenzonitrile 162 to produce 163, which underwent Cadogan–Sundberg reaction to generate dinitrile 164. Finally, P2S5-mediated cyclization reaction of 164, 167, and 171 afforded the desired synucleozid derivatives 165, 168, and 172. The main reason for selecting synucleozid structures was to improve blood–brain barrier (BBB) penetrance, based on CNS multiparameter optimization (MPO) scores. 2-AP fluorescence binding assay revealed that the replacement of the guanidyl groups of synucleozid 173 with imidazolyl groups to generate 165, 168, and 172 improved the CNS MPO scores of the compounds without reducing their avidity for the SNCA IRE structure. However, the ability of the synucleozid analogues to block α-synuclein expression in SH-SY5Y cells was reduced; approximately 67% and 40% reductions of α-synuclein levels were observed using synucleozid (173) at 1 μM and its derivatives (165, 168, 171) at 5 μM, respectively. Mechanistic investigations showed that synucleozid 173 affects ribosomal assembly onto the SNCA mRNA by stabilizing the IRE structure and inhibiting its unfolding process. A similar approach might be applicable to other disease-causing undruggable proteins encoded by mRNAs with IREs.

    3.2. Synthetic Molecules Targeting mRNA Splicing Process

    Tau is a microtubule-associated protein produced by mRNAs in neurons.(93) Aberrant aggregation of tau protein in neuronal cells and axons is a key feature of the pathology of neurodegenerative diseases such as dementia, Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s disease.(94) However, tau is not easily druggable, and alternative approaches are needed.(95) In this context, Artigas and Marchán reported four classes of ametantrone-based small molecules, i.e., ametantrone 176, guanidinoneamine 186, neamine 187, and azaquinolone 189, that target tau pre-mRNAs, and investigated their RNA-binding ability.(96) Ametantrone itself (176, in which Boc is replaced by H) was identified as a promising RNA ligand with low cytotoxicity in eukaryotic cells.(97,98) As shown in Scheme 30, nucleophilic aromatic substitution reaction of 1,4-difluoroanthraquinone 174 with N-(2-hydroxyethyl)ethylenediamine 175 gave N-Boc protected ametantrone 176, followed by Mitsunobu reaction and hydrolysis to yield intermediates 179 and 180. Treatment of thiol-containing neamine 181 with 2,2′-dithiobis(5-nitropyridine) 182 and subsequent reaction with monothiol derivative 179 provided the corresponding disulfide intermediate 184 (Scheme 28b). The desired compound 186 was finally obtained via the reaction of 184 with N,N′-di-Boc-N″-triflylguanidine 185, followed by acidic deprotection of Boc. Similar approaches were employed for the synthesis of 187 and 189, starting from the reaction of 183 and bis-thiol derivative 180 (Scheme 30). Azaquinolone and guanidinoneamine heterocycles are useful structures to increase RNA-binding affinity via hydrogen-bonding pairing with adenine in RNA stem-loop structures, as well as to improve cellular uptake. Guanidinylated analogue 186 displayed the highest binding affinity for tau mRNA, with the EC50 value of 57.2 nM. The effect of the ligands on the thermodynamic stability of tau mRNA bearing mutated sequences seen in patients suffering from chromosome 17-related frontotemporal dementia and parkinsonism (FTDP-17) was also investigated. Intronic mutations generally reduce the stability of the tau pre-mRNA stem-loop structure, resulting in abnormal splicing. Stabilizing tau pre-mRNA with organic ligands might be helpful to regulate the splicing mechanism and might suppress the development of neurodegenerative disorders. Indeed, the synthesized heterocycles increased the thermodynamic stability of mutated sequences of tau pre-mRNA by approximately 4 °C and thus could be considered as regulators of the tau pre-mRNA splicing process. This study provides a new strategy to design mRNA ligands based on amentantrone with increased RNA-binding affinity. Research is needed to explore the availability of these types of heterocycles for targeting other RNA secondary structures therapeutically relevant to human diseases.
    Disney’s group used a combination of 3D modeling and Inforna approaches to discover bioactive small molecules with high binding affinity for tau pre-mRNA, aiming to suppress 4 repeat (4R) tau levels in FTDP-17.(99) They constructed an in vitro assay system in which the A-bulge of tau pre-mRNA was replaced with 2-AP in models of the WT and disinhibition-dementia-parkinsonism-amyotrophy complex hairpins. In this assay, binding of small molecules to the labeled sites reduces the fluorescence intensity. Screening of 200 compounds, including some commercial products, identified 193 as the most potent ligand with high binding affinity (Kd = 4.9 μM) and an IC50 value of 2.1 μM. They synthesized 193via conversion of readily available ethyl 3-amino-5-methoxy-1H-indole-2-carboxylate 190 to imine derivative 191, followed by pyrimidone formation (Scheme 31). Cell-based luciferase assay revealed no toxicity of the ligand up to 100 μM concentration. NMR spectroscopic analysis of the ligand–tau RNA complex supported the idea that compound 193 improves the stability of the tau pre-mRNA hairpin structure through hydrogen-bonding interactions with base pairs close to the A-bulge. There are generally six tau isoforms in human cells, resulting from alternative splicing of three exons (2, 3, 10) of the tau gene, of which exon 10 is responsible for the three and four carboxyl-terminal microtubule-binding repeats (3R and 4R) isoforms. While there is an equimolar 4R/3R ratio in normal human cells, an increased 4R/3R ratio is associated with tau aggregation in neurodegenerative diseases.(100) The effect of compound 193 on tau in LAN5 neuroblastoma cells and humanized tau mouse primary neurons was also investigated, and ∼40% and ∼50% reductions of the 4R/3R ratios were observed for neuroblastoma cells and primary cortical neurons, respectively. Having a good CNS MPO score of 4.4, ligand 193 was predicted to display promising brain penetration and thus might have reasonable ADME characteristics.
    In general, a pre-mRNA hairpin structure close to exon 10 controls the splicing process in pre-mRNA producing tau protein. Disease-causing mutations that modify this pre-mRNA structure significantly enhance the splicing in exon 10, resulting in aberrant aggregation of tau protein in neuronal cells. Accordingly, stabilizing the stem loop of mRNA with small molecules may reduce the inclusion of exon 10, offering a new therapeutic strategy to treat various neurodegenerative diseases. On the basis of this concept, Wolfe’s group identified compound 204 (Scheme 32) as an inhibitor of tau exon 10 pre-mRNA splicing by means of RNA-directed in situ Hüisgen 1,3-cycloaddition reaction of mitoxantrones (MTXs) with an azide linker (202 and its analogues, Scheme 32) and bipartite ASOs bearing a terminal alkyne (203 and its analogues, Scheme 32).(101) It was anticipated that the anthracene-dione core of MTX derivatives would assist their binding to pre-mRNA hairpin structure in a suitable orientation via strong interactions of the two amino alcohol substitutions and the aromatic rings with the RNA groove. Mitoxantrone 202a itself was previously reported to display high potency in stabilizing the tau mRNA stem-loop via hydrogen bonding between the amine and hydroxyl groups of MTX and GC base pairs in the mRNA structure.(102) Peptide-nucleic acid (PNA) scaffolds with short sequences were also utilized as the bipartite ASOs component due to their strong binding ability to RNAs.(103) With these components in hand, RNA-directed in situ click reactions were performed using tau mRNA template, MTX azides, and bipartite PNA alkynes in water at room temperature. Interestingly, Hüisgen 1,3-cycloaddition reaction between MTX azides and PNA alkynes only proceeded in the presence of the mRNA template, suggesting that concurrent binding of these components to the RNA brings the azide and alkyne groups into close proximity in appropriate orientation to facilitate the 1,3-cycloaddition reaction. They finally identified conjugate 204 as an inhibitor of tau exon 10 pre-mRNA splicing. This study was the first example of RNA template-directed synthesis of small molecule RNA inhibitors. The synthesis of 204 is illustrated in Scheme 32. Two successive N-protection reactions of diethylenetriamine 194 followed by partial N-deprotection provided the intermediate 197, which was treated with [2-(2-azidoethoxy)ethoxy]acetic acid 198 to give azide compound 199. The nucleophilic aromatic substitution of commercially available anthracene-dione 200 with 199 and N-(2-aminoethyl)ethanolamine 175 and subsequent N-Boc deprotection afforded MTX azide 202. Hüisgen 1,3-cycloaddition reaction of MTX azide 202 and resin-supported bipartite PNA alkyne oligomer 203 in the presence of Cu(MeCN)4PF6 catalyst gave the corresponding conjugate, which was finally cleaved from the resin under acidic conditions to afford 204. While the well-known anticancer agent MTX displayed high cytotoxicity (∼100 nM), the conjugate 204 was much less cytotoxic (∼1 μM). Unfortunately, the cytotoxicity of 204 is still too high for in vivo analysis of pre-mRNA splicing, so a cell-free in vitro splicing assay was employed. Compound 204 showed potent inhibitory activity (complete inhibition at 500 nM) of tau exon 10 pre-mRNA splicing compared with either PNA or MTX alone.
    Spinal muscular atrophy (SMA) is a neurodegenerative disorder in which motor neurons in the spinal cord and brain stem are progressively destroyed, resulting in muscle wasting and weakness.(104) Survival motor neuron (SMN) protein, encoded by SMN1 and SMN2 genes, plays a fundamental role in the development and function of motor neurons in the CNS. Either homozygous deletion or mutation of the SMN1 gene and abnormal splicing of the SMN2 gene contribute to the onset of SMA. In SMA, SMN2 pre-mRNA undergoes an unusual splicing process to form SMN2Δ7 mRNA, which generates an unstable SMNΔ7 protein. This phenomenon results in a reduced amount of SMN2 mRNA and consequently an insufficient level of SMN protein, leading to more severe SMA symptoms over time. In this regard, shifting the splicing process of SMN2 to the generation of SMN2 mRNAs by targeting the pre-mRNA with small molecules might be a promising strategy to increase the level of SMN protein. Risdiplam has recently been developed as a selective SMN2 gene splicing modulator for the treatment of SMA.(105) Risdiplam 211 is an improved version of compound 213, the first SMN2 pre-mRNA splicing modifier to enter human clinical trials. Although 213 increased the levels of SMN protein up to 2-fold in patients, retinal toxicity was observed in cynomolgus monkeys after 39 weeks of daily oral dosing. Risdiplam 211, in which this adverse effect of 213 is reduced, has been approved for clinical use under the brand name Evrysdi. In the synthesis of 211, 3,6-dichloro-4-methylpyridazine 205 initially undergoes a consecutive nucleophilic substitution/N-alkylation/intramolecular cyclization reaction in the presence of aqueous ammonia and 1-bromo-2,2-dimethoxypropane to give imidazopyridazine 206 (Scheme 33). Treatment of 206 with bis(pinacolato)diboron affords the corresponding boronic acid pinacol ester 207, which reacts with pyrimidin-4-one 209, prepared from 2-amino-5-fluoropyridine 208 and then with a piperazine derivative to finally produce 211. The SAR study suggested that the presence of the pyrazine nitrogens is critical for high potency. Risdiplam 211 was significantly more potent (EC1.5× = 4 nM) than ligand 213 (EC1.5× = 23 nM) in an in vitro SMN2 pre-mRNA splicing assay. Furthermore, the amount of SMN protein in SMA type I fibroblasts was increased by approximately 2-fold in the presence of 211 (1 μM). In metabolism studies using human liver microsomes and human hepatocytes, N-hydroxylated analogue 212 was identified as the main metabolite but displayed no activity toward SMN2 splicing. The pharmacokinetic profile of risdiplam 211 was examined in rats and cynomolgus monkeys upon intravenous and oral administration. Risdiplam showed a significantly reduced volume of distribution (Vss) of 3.1 L/kg (in rats) and 2.0 L/kg (in cynomolgus monkeys) when administered at 1.9 mg/kg intravenously, compared to compound 213, which showed Vss = 29 L/kg in rat and Vss = 20 L/kg in cynomolgus monkey at the intravenous dose of 2.0 mg/kg (Scheme 33). Risdiplam also displayed a favorable half-life range of T1/2 = 5.4–6.4 h upon oral administration of 5.5 mg/kg in these animal experiments. The effects of risdiplam 211 on the hERG channel and on phospholipidosis were also investigated in in vivo assays. No marked changes of hERG K+ current and no phospholipidosis were detected in any tissues after administration for up to 26 and 39 weeks in rats and cynomolgus monkeys, respectively. No evidence of toxicity was observed in the in vitro and in vivo studies. Neuromuscular pathological examination of SMAΔ7 mice treated with 211 from PND3 to PND14 at doses in the range of 0.1–1 mg kg–1 day–1 revealed increases in the number of motor neurons, muscle size, and proportion of fully innervated neuromuscular junctions in SMNΔ7 mice given the dose of 0.3 mg/kg.
    Soon after the discovery of risdiplam 211, Cheung and co-workers developed a synthetic small molecule as an SMN2 pre-mRNA splicing modifier to stabilize the interaction between SMN2 pre-mRNA and spliceosome.(106) Branaplam 215 was discovered by high-throughput phenotypic screening, followed by optimization of the lead structure 214 (Scheme 34). Compound 214 showed outstanding activation of the SMN2 reporter by 1700% with EC50 = 3.5 μM. In a mouse SMN ELISA analysis, 214 exhibited 2.5-fold increase in the level of SMN protein with an EC50 value of 0.6 μM. An in vivo pharmacokinetics of 214 in mice revealed a high plasma clearance of 113 mL min–1 kg–1 with moderate bioavailability (F = 18%) and poor CNS exposure. Accordingly, further efforts were focused on improving the potency, maximizing the in vivo exposure by decreasing the clearance and increasing the permeability, and reducing the hERG channel-binding liability. A comprehensive SAR study identified key structural parameters for improvement. The introduction of an ortho-hydroxyl group on the aromatic ring next to the pyridazine core resulted in a substantial increase in the potency of 214 in SMN ELISA assay. It was also found that addition of a pyrazole group to the structure retained high SMN potency with reduced hERG binding. Changing the N-methylamine linker in 214 to an oxygen moiety, affording compound 215, greatly improved brain exposure in SMNΔ7 mice (Scheme 34). Synthetically, Suzuki coupling reaction between pyridazine derivative 218 and 4-chloro-2-hydroxyphenylboronic acid pinacol ester 220 catalyzed by PdCl2(dppf)·DCM afforded the intermediate 221. A second Suzuki coupling between 221 and 1-Boc-pyrazole-4-boronic acid pinacol ester 222 in the presence of BrettPhos Pd G1 (Buchwald first generation (G1) palladacycle precatalyst) provided the Boc-protected species 223, and N-Boc deprotection under acidic conditions afforded branaplam 215 in 47% overall yield.

    3.3. Synthetic Molecules Targeting mRNA Repeats

    Myotonic dystrophy type 1 (DM1) is a multisystem skeletal muscle disorder caused by the misregulation of pre-mRNA splicing. Expansion of r(CUG) repeats to form r(CUG)exp leads to aberrant sequestration of muscle blind-like 1 protein (MBNL1) in muscle cells, where r(CUG)exp wrinkles to form a stretched hairpin structure that provides several high-affinity binding sites for MBNL1.(107) Excessive binding of MBNL1 to the RNA significantly decreases free MBNL1 levels and affects cellular functions, leading to DM1. Therefore, targeting the r(CUG)exp transcript in pre-mRNA with synthetic small molecules could be effective to block the binding sites for MBNL1 and restore its activity. Zimmerman and co-workers designed a new triaminotriazine-containing heterocyclic scaffold 230 (Scheme 35) to target CUG units of pre-mRNA, on the basis of a molecular modeling approach.(108) Groove-binding compound 230 was expected to be capable of covering three sequential CUG sites in the mRNA duplex, with the two triaminotriazine groups of the ligand forming strong base triplets with the corresponding U–U mismatches (Scheme 35a,b). Furthermore, superposing the r(CUG)6 duplex structure (PDB: 3GM7) on the stem-loop region of HIV-1 FS RNA (PDB: 2L94) revealed an extraordinary similarity between the two RNA motifs (Scheme 35b). The mechanism through which 230 binds to pre-mRNA and interrupts MBNL1N-RNA complex formation is not fully established. On the other hand, recent studies have demonstrated that small molecules that interact with CTG-rich DNA also reduce CUG RNA levels through the inhibition of transcription.(109,110) Therefore, it seems possible that 230 binds to CTG DNA to reduce expanded CUG repeat RNA. For the synthesis of 230, diethyl terephthalimidate 225 and N2-(4-aminobutyl)-1,3,5-triazine-2,4,6-triamine 229 were first prepared via acid-mediated ethanolysis of 1,4-dicyanobenzene 224 and nucleophilic substitution reaction of 2-chloro-4,6-diamino-1,3,5-triazine 228 with 1,4-diaminobutane 227, respectively (Scheme 35). The intermediate 226, which was synthesized by the reaction of 225 and N,N-dimethylpropylaminein ethanolic HCl, was then reacted with 229 in the presence of ethylene glycol and Et3N to afford 230. The activity of 230 to inhibit MBNL1-CUG interaction was investigated by means of in vitro electrophoretic mobility shift assay, and an IC50 value of 115 μM was obtained. The binding affinity and selectivity of 230 for pre-mRNA were examined by isothermal titration calorimetry with several targets, including GST-tagged MBNL1, tRNA, pre-mRNA, r(CCUG)8, and HIV frameshift site RNA. They found that 230 displayed excellent selectivity and binding ability for r(CUG)12 of pre-mRNA with Kd = 8 μM, while other targets showed Kd > 200 μM. An in vivo assessment of ligand 230 against r(CUG)exp-induced toxicity was also carried out using a DM1 transgenic Drosophila assay, and a significant reversal of pre-mRNA missplicing defects was detected in DM1-infected Drosophila flies. Compound 230 showed no cytotoxicity to human DM1 and 3T3 mouse fibroblast cells up to 100 μM concentration, and the maximum tolerated dose of 230 applied as a single i.p. injection in mice was between 50 and 100 mg/kg. Thus, 230 appears to be a promising candidate for treatment of DM1.
