    Bio-orthogonal chemical reactions are increasingly used to selectively synthesize a wide range of products.(111) Tetrazine ligation is a bio-orthogonal cycloaddition reaction that can occur between 1,2,4,5-tetrazines and different dienophiles catalyzed by RNA templates and has been used for live-cell imaging.(112) Disney’s group demonstrated that r(CUG)exp was capable of catalyzing the in situ synthesis of an mRNA inhibitor via bio-orthogonal cycloaddition between a tetrazine and a cyclopropene in DM1-derived living cells.(113) Peptide 239 with tetrazine and cyclopropane moiety was initially designed to target r(CUG)exp by means of the Inforna approach and was synthesized from readily accessible starting materials (Scheme 36,36a,b). The coupling reaction of tert-butyl [4-(methylamino)butyl]carbamate or tert-butyl [2-(methylamino)ethyl]carbamate (231) with allyl chloroformate 232 provided allyloxycarbonyl (Alloc)-protected amines 233 (Scheme 36a). N-Boc deprotection, Rink amide resin activation, peptide chain extension on resin, Alloc deprotection, and resin removal reactions afforded 239. This peptide oligomerized upon binding to r(CUG)exp in DM1-derived cells, resulting in the in situ formation of highly potent inhibitors (240 and 241), which were 10 000-fold more active than the parent tetrazine and cyclopropene monomers. Interestingly, the total level of MBNL1 mRNA was not affected by r(CUG)exp-templated oligomerized 239, possibly due to enhancement of pre-mRNA splicing defects; approximately, 65% of MBNL1 splicing defects in DM1 cells could be rescued at the concentration of 1 μM. The r(CUG)exp-templated 239 also decreased r(CUG)exp-MBNL1-containing nuclear foci by about 50% at 1 μM concentration, supporting the idea that 239 can repair DM1-related splicing defects. A fluorogenic derivative of 239 was prepared using fluorescein alkyne 6-isomer (242, Scheme 36c). r(CUG)exp catalyzed in situ formation of its own fluorescent probe from triazine 242 and cyclopropene 243 (Scheme 36c), making it possible to visualize and monitor r(CUG)exp in living cells and DM1 mouse myofibers. This technique would allow us to broadly image various RNAs in cells and should be helpful to design novel therapeutic agents for selectively targeting RNAs, which remains one of the most challenging aspects of RNA-based drug discovery.
    Similarly, Disney and co-workers reported r(CUG)exp-catalyzed in situ click synthesis of an mRNA inhibitor in DM1-affected cells (Scheme 37).(114) In their technique, a DM1-derived living cell and r(CUG)exp were utilized as a round-bottomed flask and as the catalyst, respectively, for probe synthesis. Peptide 245 with azide and alkyne moieties was designed to target r(CUG)exp by means of the Inforna method and synthesized using readily accessible starting materials (Scheme 37). This compound 245 improved DM1-associated pre-mRNA splicing defects in myotubes and myoblasts at the dosage of 100 pM, on the basis of qPCR analysis, with no effect on non-DM1 myotubes or myoblasts. In addition, 245 had no effect on the splicing process of pre-mRNAs that were not controlled by MBNL1. To compare the developed small molecule and oligonucleotides, the efficacy of a Vivo-Morpholino oligonucleotide against DM1-associated defects was analyzed in a mouse model and compared with that of 245. The latter exhibited approximately 25 000-fold greater potency than the former. Two main reasons were suggested for the high activity of 245: recognition of r(CUG)exp structure rather than sequence, and better kinetics of binding to RNAs, compared with the oligonucleotide. An in situ fluorescent probe synthesis of 246 containing FRET pairs, i.e., fluorescein amidites (FAM) and 5-carboxytetramethylrhodamine (TAMRA), was developed (Scheme 37c), and the resulting FRET sensor was used to probe DM1-affected cells. Imaging analyses showed that binding to r(CUG)exp facilitated cytoplasmic translocation of the fluorescent probe 246, allowing translation of luciferase possessing r(CUG)exp repeats in the 3′ UTR without modifying the level of luciferase mRNA. This in situ fluorescent probe synthetic platform is expected to be useful for imaging r(CUG)exp in living cells.
    Myotonic dystrophy type 2 (DM2) is another skeletal muscle disorder caused by the dysfunction of pre-mRNA splicing, where expansion of r(CCUG) repeats leads to the formation of r(CCUG)exp in pre-mRNAs.(115) This phenomenon generates high-affinity binding sites for MBNL1 in the loops, resulting in inactivation of MBNL1 upon binding and leading to DM2. Disney’s group developed an in cellulo click chemistry strategy to synthesize kanamycin A-based small molecules containing azide and alkyne groups that attach to adjacent sites in r(CCUG)exp and undergo Huisgen cycloaddition reaction.(116) Compound 251 was initially synthesized by the amide formation reaction of NBD-activated 6-aminohexynoic acid 249 with azide kanamycin A analogue 250 (Scheme 38). This molecule, containing both azide and alkyne moieties, can generate an oligomer 252in cellulo that is a potent inhibitor of DM2 mRNA dysfunction. To investigate the selectivity of r-(CCUG) for oligomer formation, several RNAs, including r(AUUCU)12, r(CUG)12, r(CAG)12, r(CGG)12, an RNA hairpin with a fully paired stem, and tRNA, were studied. Among them, only r(CUG)12 generated a substantial amount of products. A cellular model system expressing r(CCUG)300 was utilized to test the possibility of templating multivalent compounds in cellulo. No oligomerization occurred in cells with no RNA expression, and the templated synthesis of the oligomer took place only in disease-affected cells, indicating that r(CCUG)300 catalyzes the synthesis of its own inhibitor in cellulo. The oligomer 252 was >1000-fold more active than the parent monomer and rescued approximately 70% of MBNL1 splicing defects in DM2 cells at the concentration of 10 μM. This study of the biological effects of the templated compounds on DM2-associated defects in living cells suggests that the approach may have therapeutic potential.
    Repeat expansion of RNA is a pathogenic process associated with many neurodegenerative diseases. Spinocerebellar ataxia type 10 (SCA10) is an autosomal major cerebellar ataxia that displays severe cerebellar dysfunctions, peripheral neuropathy, and epilepsy.(117) SCA10 is caused by an RNA gain-of-function process due to expansion of r(AUUCU) repeats at intron 9 of the ataxin 10 mRNA, leading to the formation of defective proteins. Disney’s group employed a two-dimensional combinatorial screening method to probe small molecules for binding affinity to GC and AU base pairs of RNA hairpin structure.(118) Among a library of compounds including benzimidazole, benzamidine, and aniline derivatives, they identified compound 256 bearing a benzamidine core as the most selective ligand for AU base pairs (∼40-fold selectivity over GC pairs). Pd-catalyzed cross-coupling reaction of 4-bromobenzonitrile 131 and furan 132 afforded 4,4′-(furan-2,5-diyl)dibenzonitrile 133, which underwent acid-mediated ethanolysis to give the corresponding diethyl 4,4′-(furan-2,5-diyl)dibenzimidate hydrochloride 253 in quantitative yield. Neutralizing 253 with Et3N followed by reaction with azidopropylamine 113 and purging with NH3 gas finally afforded 254. The binding ability of compound 254 to the r(AUUCU) repeats in mRNAs of SCA10 cells was then evaluated. Ligand 254 exhibited high affinity for r(AUUCU)11, containing 10 AU pairs, with a Kd value of 300 nM, with a stoichiometry of approximately 11:1 (254:r(AUUCU)11). Encouraged by these results, they designed and synthesized dimer 256 by conjugating 254 onto a peptoid backbone via Cu(I)-catalyzed Huisgen cycloaddition reaction (Scheme 39). The binding ability of 256 to r(AUUCU)11 was approximately 2-fold higher than that of the monomer 254 (Kd = 185 nM). Since caspase 3 is aberrantly induced in SCA10 fibroblasts, they examined the effect of dimer 256 on the caspase-3 activity in SCA10 patient-derived fibroblasts and found that the caspase-3 activity was decreased to normal levels at 50 nM concentration. Furthermore, upon treatment of SCA10 cells with 256 for 48 h, the formation of nuclear foci was decreased by approximately 70%. Ligand 256 showed no apparent cytotoxicity at 50 nM, indicating that its bioactivity was due to binding to r(AAUCU)exp in the mRNAs. Thus, 256 and its analogues are candidate therapeutic agents for SCA10.

    3.4. Synthetic Molecules Targeting Viral mRNAs

    Human immunodeficiency virus type-1 (HIV-1) is a lipid-enveloped retrovirus that causes progressive failure of the immune system. HIV-1 trans-acting responsive region (TAR) is positioned at the 5′ end of all HIV-1 mRNAs and binds to viral proteins such as trans-activator of transcription (Tat), a transactivator of the HIV-1 long terminal repeat, to generate ribonucleoprotein complexes.(119) Tat is associated with several cellular events in HIV-1, including transcription and viral replication, via binding to the TAR RNA structure. Thus, TAR RNA has become a promising target of drug development to suppress HIV-1 viral replication. Although RNA targeting research in drug discovery has often focused on peptides and oligonucleotide-based antisense derivatives, these strategies suffer from insufficient specificity, poor cellular uptake, and intrinsic instability, and synthetic small molecules might overcome these disadvantages. Benhida and co-workers reported the synthesis of two types of conjugates with either one amino acid (263) or two amino acid (266) units (Scheme 40) to investigate their suppressive activity against HIV-1 TAR RNAs.(120) They selected basic amino acids to synthesize the ligands due to their potential for strong electrostatic interactions with the bulge bases of the RNAs.(121) The key intermediate 261 was first synthesized through α-bromination of commercially available 3-nitroacetophenone 257 followed by thiazole formation and nitro reduction (Scheme 40a). The preparation of conjugate 263 with one amino acid consisted of two steps: coupling of 261 with various N-protected amino acids and N-deprotection. The ligands 266 bearing two amino acids were also synthesized via coupling reaction of 261 with N-Boc-protected diaminopropanoic acid 264 as a linker, followed by deprotection, reaction with various N-Boc-protected amino acids, and deprotection (Scheme 40b). The obtained compounds were examined for binding ability to HIV-1 TAR RNA by means of fluorescence measurements using a labeled TAR fragment. As expected, compounds bearing two basic amino acids (266) exhibited high binding affinity compared to those with one amino acid (263), due to the presence of four additional hydrogen-bonding interactions with C and G bases (Scheme 40c). Among the synthesized compounds, compounds 263a (monoarginine) and 266a (diarginine) showed the best performance, with Kd values of 2.4 μM and 0.11 μM, respectively. The selectivity of active ligands was then examined using a 100-fold excess of tRNA and double-stranded DNA. Compounds 266b (monohistidine) and 266b (dilysine) were the most selective TAR RNA binders (Scheme 40b). Circular dichroism analysis of the TAR hairpin conducted in the presence and absence of 266b as a model ligand revealed that the ligand-RNA interaction caused no major change of the RNA structure and did not abolish the overall base stacking. Next, the suppressive activity of potent compounds against HIV-1 replication in MAGIC-5B cells was assessed. There was a close relationship between selectivity and antiviral activity. Indeed, ligands with low specificity were completely inactive. Compound 263a (histidine) showed the most potent inhibitory activity, with the IC50 value of 0.41 μM. Furthermore, when various concentrations of 263a (0.1–100 μM) were incubated with MAGIC-5B cells for 48 h, no cytotoxicity was observed, suggesting that further in vivo investigations would be warranted.
    Dash et al. carried out in situ click chemistry using a large number of alkynes 267 with thiazole ring systems and azides 268 and discovered anti-(1,4)-triazoles 269 as potential HIV-1 TAR-Tat inhibitors (Scheme 41).(122) In a 5′-biotin-tagged 29-nucleotide TAR RNA model system, the TAR RNA served as a template for the cycloaddition reaction, and the cyclized products were easily separated from the reaction mixture by using streptavidin magnetic beads. Interestingly, the Cu(I)-catalyzed cyclization reaction of alkynes and azides gave a mixture of anti-(1,4)- and syn-(1,5)-triazole regioisomers, but the in situ RNA-templated reaction provided exclusively the anti-1,4-triazole isomer. Among the triazoles, 269a and 269b displayed potent binding affinity for TAR RNA with Kd = 0.54 μM and Kd = 6.7 μM, respectively. They showed DC50 values of 1.5 and 10.6 μM, respectively (DC50 is the concentration of a ligand causing 50% displacement of Tat from TAR RNA). Molecular modeling studies suggested that 269a interacts with the bulge sites of the RNA, while 269b binds to the major groove region. The flexible methylene unit of the left-hand thiazole ring in 269a (Scheme 41) appeared to facilitate interaction with the bulge sites. Further cell-based studies might lead to the development of new TAR RNA inhibitors as antiviral agents.
    In addition, Al-Hashim and co-workers reported the de novo discovery of some TAR RNA binders, including netilmicin and MTX 202a (Scheme 32), by in silico screening.(123) Netilmicin selectively binds to HIV TAR and inhibits HIV-1 replication with an IC50 value of 23.1 μM. Thus, HIV-1 TAR RNA binders might be candidate anti-HIV agents.

    3.5. Synthetic Molecules Targeting Bacterial mRNAs

    Riboswitches are cis regulatory structural elements located in the UTR of mRNAs that specifically bind natural ligands to regulate gene expression in many microbial species.(124) Riboswitches interact with metabolites such as vitamins, amino acids, S-adenosylmethionine, glucosamine-6-phosphate, and flavin mononucleotide (FMN), which induce a conformational alteration that modulates the expression of components of the relevant biosynthetic pathways. Riboflavin (vitamin B2) is essential for microbial growth, and FMN riboswitches modulate gene expression of transporters and enzymes involved in riboflavin biosynthesis.(125) Therefore, disturbing riboflavin biosynthesis could be a suitable strategy for the prevention of bacterial cell growth. A group of scientists at Merck Research Laboratories discovered ribocil 277 as a highly selective synthetic modifier of bacterial riboflavin riboswitches.(126) This synthetic mimic of FMN was designed to compete with the natural ligand in order to stop FMN riboswitch-mediated mRNA expression of genes associated with riboflavin biosynthesis. They screened a library of approximately 57 000 synthetic compounds with antibacterial activity to identify molecules exhibiting growth-inhibitory activity toward Escherichia coli strain MB5746. On the basis of this phenotypic screen, they discovered ribocil 277 (Scheme 42), which blocks riboflavin biosynthesis with an IC50 value of 0.3 μM. This potent ligand was prepared in five simple synthetic steps from commercially available thiophene-2-carbonyl chloride 270 (Scheme 42a). Nucleophilic acyl substitution reaction between 270 and ethyl acetate initially gave ethyl 3-oxo-3-(thiophen-2-yl)propanoate 271, followed by nucleophilic addition of ammonia to provide acrylamide 272. Oxidative annulation-aromatization reaction between 272 and 1-tert-butyl 3-methylpiperidine-1,3-dicarboxylate 273 generated pyrimidine derivative 274. Finally, sequentialN-Boc deprotection/reductive amination afforded ribocil 277 (Scheme 42a). To clarify the cellular target of ribocil 277 and its mechanism of action, several ribocil-resistant E. coli mutants were independently isolated and their drug-resistant mutations were investigated via whole-genome sequencing (WGS). All drug-resistant mutants showed base-pair variations mapping to the FMN riboswitch. Furthermore, none of the detected mutations served as compensatory mutations. The absence of additional mutations in all ribocil-resistant isolates detected by WGS clearly implicated the FMN riboswitch as a fundamental element for ribocil resistance. On the basis of these findings, it was hypothesized that ribocil 277 prevents riboflavin biosynthesis directly through mimicking the FMN ligand and binding to the FMN riboswitch to impair mRNA expression of riboflavin. To test this idea, a plasmid-based GFP reporter gene was utilized under the control of E. coli riboflavin promoter and FMN riboswitch 5′ sequence of mRNA in a ribocil-resistant isolate. This technique enables a ribocil-mediated effect on the expression of GFP to be measured without inhibiting cell growth. Ribocil 277 potently inhibited GFP expression with an EC50 value of 0.3 μM. Ribocil 277 also effectively repressed GFP reporter expression controlled by orthologous riboswitches from Acinetobacter baumannii and Pseudomonas aeruginosa, with approximately 5-fold higher EC50 than that observed for the E. coli riboswitch. In contrast, GFP reporter constructs harboring E. coli ribocil-resistant riboswitch mutations were mostly unresponsive to inhibition by ribocil 277, further supporting the importance of a direct interaction between ribocil 277 and the riboswitch. Following unsuccessful attempts to cocrystallize the E. coli FMN aptamer with ribocil 277, the X-ray crystal structure of ribocil 277 bound to the Fusobacterium nucleatum impX FMN riboswitch aptamer was successfully obtained (Scheme 42b). In the complex, ribocil 277 adopts a forced U-shaped conformation and is located inside the junctional area of the six mRNAs. The 6-thiophenyl-pyrimidonyl group of ribocil 277 stacks face-to-face between A48 and A85 and edge-to-face with A49. Hydrogen bond formation between the pyrimidonyl oxygen of ribocil 277 and A48 and A99 is critical. Furthermore, the (methylamino)pyrimidinyl group of 277 stacks face-to-face with G62, and a weak hydrogen bond is formed between the hydrogen at position 5 of the piperazine of 277 and G11. Although a racemic mixture of ribocil 277 was employed for cocrystallization, electron density mapping of the cocrystal structure showed that only the (S)-isomer is bound in the cocrystal, and this may be the biologically active form. In vivo activity of ribocil 277 in a murine systemic infection model of E. coli was investigated. In this experiment, female DBA/2J mice were infected with E. coli strain MB5746 (5.0 × 104 CFU per mouse) viai.p. injection and subsequently treated by subcutaneous injection with ribocil-C ((S)-isomer of 277) at various doses (120, 60, or 30 mg/kg) 3 times over an infection period of 24 h. Spleens were then aseptically collected from five mice per group and the reduction of log[CFU per g spleen tissue] was measured, on the basis of the bacterial burden in spleens of the vehicle-treated (10% DMSO) control group. Significant reductions were observed from 9.53 log[CFU per g spleen] in the vehicle-treated group to 7.76 log[CFU per g spleen] and 6.24 log[CFU per g spleen] in in the 60 and 120 mg/kg ribocil-C treatment groups, with no mortality or gross toxic effects. This study suggests high pharmacological potential of ribocil 277 as an antimicrobial agent.

    Conclusion and Perspectives

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Chemotherapy and radiotherapy are often unsuccessful in patients with advanced cancer, e.g., showing invasion and metastasis, due to drug resistance.(127) Various factors may be involved, including altered drug transport or metabolism, inactivation, and genetic and epigenetic changes in the tumor cells. In this context, synthetic RNA-targeting molecules represent a promising strategy to treat drug-resistant cancers. Regulating gene expression in cancer cells with synthetic RNA modulators can cause primary genotypic variations that affect the cell life cycle and promote apoptosis of tumor cells. Apart from cancers, many other human diseases are associated with dysfunction of cellular proteins, which may be undruggable due to the lack of binding pockets. In such cases, a fascinating new strategy to knock down the undruggable proteins is to target their encoding mRNAs and thereby inhibit their translation. For this purpose, we require high selectivity and binding affinity for a specific RNA, excellent cellular uptake, low cytotoxicity, and stability. Synthetic molecules can provide these advantages, together with great structural diversity and relatively easy tunability of their physicochemical and pharmacological characteristics. In this review, we have highlighted the current status of research on synthetic RNA modulators as chemical probes to reverse severe cellular dysfunctions. Recent advances in RNA sequencing, structural confirmation by X-ray crystallography, in vitro and in vivo chemical RNA probing, and biophysical techniques have provided powerful interdisciplinary approaches to identify druggable human-disease-causing RNAs, opening up numerous avenues for further exploration of new synthetic ligands in drug design. Nevertheless, this field is still at an early stage of development, and although synthetic RNA-targeting compounds show great promise, high potency in in vitro assays does not necessarily predict on-target efficacy in living cells. Thus, further research employing target engagement strategies based on in vivo assays will be needed to explore targeting of RNAs by synthetic molecules. Improvements in efficient screening technologies such as Inforna may lead to the establishment of rational methodologies to design synthetic molecules directly from sequence data. Furthermore, the activities of most reported RNA modulators remain at around μM level, and in many cases it is not clear whether the RNA-binding activity is linked to the effect on cell phenotype. Therefore, there is a great need for further mechanistic studies to establish the modes of action of these compounds. On the basis of the current experimental data, many of these synthetic molecules may also be recognized as modulators of RNA-binding proteins (RBPs) to alter RBP function and lead to the production of new therapeutics, since RBP dysregulations are implicated in several cancers and neurodegenerative diseases.(128) Nevertheless, the available data justify a degree of optimizm, and it seems likely that structural optimization by medicinal chemists will lead to more potent and selective modulators that show clear activity at the cellular level. We hope this review will be especially useful in helping medical researchers to better understand potential future applications of these modulators in clinical therapy for cancer and other diseases.

    Author Information

    1. 1
      Walsh, G.; Jefferis, R. Post-translational modifications in the context of therapeutic proteins. Nat. Biotechnol. 2006, 24, 1241– 1252,  DOI: 10.1038/nbt1252
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      1
      Post-translational modifications in the context of therapeutic proteins
      Walsh, Gary; Jefferis, Roy
      Nature Biotechnology (2006), 24 (10), 1241-1252CODEN: NABIF9; ISSN:1087-0156. (Nature Publishing Group)
      A review. The majority of protein-based biopharmaceuticals approved or in clin. trials bear some form of post-translational modification (PTM), which can profoundly affect protein properties relevant to their therapeutic application. Whereas glycosylation represents the most common modification, addnl. PTMs, including carboxylation, hydroxylation, sulfation, and amidation, are characteristic of some products. The relation between structure and function is understood for many PTMs but remains incomplete for others, particularly in the case of complex PTMs, such as glycosylation. A better understanding of such structure-function relations will facilitate the development of 2nd-generation products displaying a PTM profile engineered to optimize therapeutic usefulness.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XhtVGgsrnK&md5=3376c8170602376c6fe0505c32533828
    2. 2
      Deribe, Y. L.; Pawson, T.; Dikic, I. Post-translational modifications in signal integration. Nat. Struct. Mol. Biol. 2010, 17, 666– 672,  DOI: 10.1038/nsmb.1842
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      2
      Post-translational modifications in signal integration
      Deribe, Yonathan Lissanu; Pawson, Tony; Dikic, Ivan
      Nature Structural & Molecular Biology (2010), 17 (6), 666-672CODEN: NSMBCU; ISSN:1545-9993. (Nature Publishing Group)
      A review. Post-translational modifications of proteins and the domains that recognize these modifications play central roles in creating a highly dynamic relay system that reads and responds to alterations in the cellular microenvironment. Here, the authors review the common principles of post-translational modifications and their importance in signal integration underlying epidermal growth factor receptor signaling and endocytosis, DNA-damage responses, and immunity.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXmsVWmsLw%253D&md5=4486fed28be542d6f49aae1405c85ee7
    3. 3
      Wang, Y.; Peterson, S.; Loring, J. Protein post-translational modifications and regulation of pluripotency in human stem cells. Cell Res. 2014, 24, 143– 160,  DOI: 10.1038/cr.2013.151
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      3
      Protein post-translational modifications and regulation of pluripotency in human stem cells
      Wang, Yu-Chieh; Peterson, Suzanne E.; Loring, Jeanne F.
      Cell Research (2014), 24 (2), 143-160CODEN: CREEB6; ISSN:1001-0602. (NPG Nature Asia-Pacific)
      A review. Post-translational modifications (PTMs) are known to be essential mechanisms used by eukaryotic cells to diversify their protein functions and dynamically coordinate their signaling networks. Defects in PTMs have been linked to numerous developmental disorders and human diseases, highlighting the importance of PTMs in maintaining normal cellular states. Human pluripotent stem cells (hPSCs), including embryonic stem cells (hESCs) and induced pluripotent stem cells (hiPSCs), are capable of self-renewal and differentiation into a variety of functional somatic cells; these cells hold a great promise for the advancement of biomedical research and clin. therapy. The mechanisms underlying cellular pluripotency in human cells have been extensively explored in the past decade. In addn. to the vast amt. of knowledge obtained from the genetic and transcriptional research in hPSCs, there is a rapidly growing interest in the stem cell biol. field to examine pluripotency at the protein and PTM level. This review addresses recent progress toward understanding the role of PTMs (glycosylation, phosphorylation, acetylation and methylation) in the regulation of cellular pluripotency.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXhslyrtr3N&md5=4d3f8b4cb9a995f25993a675ec9c4f33
    4. 4
      Hopkins, A. L.; Groom, C. R. The druggable genome. Nat. Rev. Drug Discovery 2002, 1, 727– 730,  DOI: 10.1038/nrd892
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      4
      Opinion: The druggable genome
      Hopkins, Andrew L.; Groom, Colin R.
      Nature Reviews Drug Discovery (2002), 1 (9), 727-730CODEN: NRDDAG; ISSN:1474-1776. (Nature Publishing Group)
      A review. An assessment of the no. of mol. targets that represent an opportunity for therapeutic intervention is crucial to the development of post-genomic research strategies within the pharmaceutical industry. Now that we know the size of the human genome, it is interesting to consider just how many mol. targets this opportunity represents. We start from the position that we understand the properties that are required for a good drug, and therefore must be able to understand what makes a good drug target.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD38XmslamtrY%253D&md5=d6dc7c67822661fe03e920695def1329
    5. 5
      Dixon, S. J.; Stockwell, B. R. Identifying druggable disease-modifying gene products. Curr. Opin. Chem. Biol. 2009, 13, 549– 555,  DOI: 10.1016/j.cbpa.2009.08.003
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      5
      Identifying druggable disease-modifying gene products
      Dixon, Scott J.; Stockwell, Brent R.
      Current Opinion in Chemical Biology (2009), 13 (5-6), 549-555CODEN: COCBF4; ISSN:1367-5931. (Elsevier B.V.)
      A review. Many disease genes encode proteins that are difficult to target directly using small mol. drugs. Improvements in libraries based on synthetic compds., natural products, and other types of mols. may ultimately allow some challenging proteins to be successfully targeted; however, these developments alone are unlikely to be sufficient. A complementary strategy exploits the functional interconnectivity of intracellular networks to find druggable targets lying upstream, downstream, or in parallel to a disease-causing gene, where modulation can influence the disease process indirectly. These targets can be selected using prior knowledge of disease-assocd. pathways or identified using phenotypic chem. and genetic screens in model organisms and cells. These approaches should facilitate the identification of effective drug targets for many genetic disorders.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXhsV2msLzJ&md5=263d9f02416aac4fad4a7e7adfdda665
    6. 6
      Warner, K. D.; Hajdin, C. E.; Weeks, K. M. Principles for targeting RNA with drug-like small molecules. Nat. Rev. Drug Discovery 2018, 17, 547– 558,  DOI: 10.1038/nrd.2018.93
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      6
      Principles for targeting RNA with drug-like small molecules
      Warner, Katherine Deigan; Hajdin, Christine E.; Weeks, Kevin M.
      Nature Reviews Drug Discovery (2018), 17 (8), 547-558CODEN: NRDDAG; ISSN:1474-1776. (Nature Research)
      RNA mols. are essential for cellular information transfer and gene regulation, and RNAs have been implicated in many human diseases. Messenger and non-coding RNAs contain highly structured elements, and evidence suggests that many of these structures are important for function. Targeting these RNAs with small mols. offers opportunities to therapeutically modulate numerous cellular processes, including those linked to undruggable protein targets. Despite this promise, there is currently only a single class of human-designed small mols. that target RNA used clin. - the linezolid antibiotics. However, a growing no. of small-mol. RNA ligands are being identified, leading to burgeoning interest in the field. Here, we discuss principles for discovering small-mol. drugs that target RNA and argue that the overarching challenge is to identify appropriate target structures - namely, in disease-causing RNAs that have high information content and, consequently, appropriate ligand-binding pockets. If focus is placed on such druggable binding sites in RNA, extensive knowledge of the typical physicochem. properties of drug-like small mols. could then enable small-mol. drug discovery for RNA targets to become (only) roughly as difficult as for protein targets.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXht1OntLnL&md5=df01185ded43db426749b9c656a04f64

      Beermann, J.; Piccoli, M. T.; Viereck, J.; Thum, T. Non-coding RNAs in development and disease: Background, mechanism, and therapeutic approaches. Physiol. Rev. 2016, 96, 1297– 1325,  DOI: 10.1152/physrev.00041.2015
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      7
      Non-coding RNAs in development and disease: background, mechanisms, and therapeutic approaches
      Beermann, Julia; Piccoli, Maria-Teresa; Viereck, Janika; Thum, Thomas
      Physiological Reviews (2016), 96 (4), 1297-1325CODEN: PHREA7; ISSN:0031-9333. (American Physiological Society)
      Advances in RNA-sequencing techniques have led to the discovery of thousands of non-coding transcripts with unknown function. There are several types of non-coding linearRNAs such as microRNAs (miRNA) and long non-coding RNAs (lncRNA), as well as circular RNAs(circRNA) consisting of a closed continuous loop. This review guides the reader through important aspects of non-coding RNA biol. This includes their biogenesis, mode of actions, physiologicalfunction, as well as their role in the disease context (such as in cancer or the cardiovascularsystem). We specically focus on non-coding RNAs as potential therapeutic targets and diagnosticbiomarkers.

    9. 9
      Mongelli, A.; Martelli, F.; Farsetti, A.; Gaetano, C. The dark that matters: Long non-coding RNAs as master regulators of cellular metabolism in non-communicable diseases. Front. Physiol. 2019, 10, 369– 405,  DOI: 10.3389/fphys.2019.00369
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      9
      The Dark That Matters: Long Non-coding RNAs as Master Regulators of Cellular Metabolism in Non-communicable Diseases
      Mongelli Alessia; Gaetano Carlo; Martelli Fabio; Farsetti Antonella
      Frontiers in physiology (2019), 10 (), 369 ISSN:1664-042X.
      Non-coding RNAs are pivotal for many cellular functions, such as splicing, gene regulation, chromosome structure, and hormone-like activity. Here, we will report about the biology and the general molecular mechanisms associated with long non-coding RNAs (lncRNAs), a class of >200 nucleotides-long ribonucleic acid sequences, and their role in chronic non-transmissible diseases. In particular, we will summarize knowledge about some of the best-characterized lncRNAs, such as H19 and MALAT1, and how they regulate carbohydrate and lipid metabolism as well as protein synthesis and degradation. Evidence is discussed about how lncRNAs expression might affect cellular and organismal metabolism and whether their modulation could provide ground for the development of innovative treatments.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BB3M3lvFyntw%253D%253D&md5=d92f9d9c49667570046473d6d93ffb50

      Ling, H.; Fabbri, M.; Calin, G. A. MicroRNAs and other non-coding RNAs as targets for anticancer drug development. Nat. Rev. Drug Discovery 2013, 12, 847– 865,  DOI: 10.1038/nrd4140

      10
      MicroRNAs and other non-coding RNAs as targets for anticancer drug development
      Ling, Hui; Fabbri, Muller; Calin, George A.
      Nature Reviews Drug Discovery (2013), 12 (11), 847-865CODEN: NRDDAG; ISSN:1474-1776. (Nature Publishing Group)
      A review. The first cancer-targeted microRNA (miRNA) drug - MRX34, a liposome-based miR-34 mimic - entered Phase I clin. trials in patients with advanced hepatocellular carcinoma in Apr. 2013, and miRNA therapeutics are attracting special attention from both academia and biotechnol. companies. Although miRNAs are the most studied non-coding RNAs (ncRNAs) to date, the importance of long non-coding RNAs (lncRNAs) is increasingly being recognized. Here, we summarize the roles of miRNAs and lncRNAs in cancer, with a focus on the recently identified novel mechanisms of action, and discuss the current strategies in designing ncRNA-targeting therapeutics, as well as the assocd. challenges.

      12
      MicroRNAs: target recognition and regulatory functions
      Bartel, David P.
      Cell (Cambridge, MA, United States) (2009), 136 (2), 215-233CODEN: CELLB5; ISSN:0092-8674. (Cell Press)
      A review. MicroRNAs (miRNAs) are endogenous ∼23 nt RNAs that play important gene-regulatory roles in animals and plants by pairing to the mRNAs of protein-coding genes to direct their posttranscriptional repression. This review outlines the current understanding of miRNA target recognition in animals and discusses the widespread impact of miRNAs on both the expression and evolution of protein-coding genes.

      Djebali, S.; Davis, C. A.; Merkel, A.; Dobin, A.; Lassmann, T.; Mortazavi, A.; Tanzer, A.; Lagarde, J.; Lin, W.; Schlesinger, F.; Xue, C.; Marinov, G. K.; Khatun, J.; Williams, B.       [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      13
      Landscape of transcription in human cells
      Djebali, Sarah; Davis, Carrie A.; Merkel, Angelika; Dobin, Alex; Lassmann, Timo; Mortazavi, Ali; Tanzer, Andrea; Lagarde, Julien; Lin, Wei; Schlesinger, Felix; Xue, Chenghai; Marinov, Georgi K.; Khatun, Jainab; Williams, Brian A.; Zaleski, Chris; Rozowsky, Joel; Roeder, Maik; Kokocinski, Felix; Abdelhamid, Rehab F.; Alioto, Tyler; Antoshechkin, Igor; Baer, Michael T.; Bar, Nadav S.; Batut, Philippe; Bell, Kimberly; Bell, Ian; Chakrabortty, Sudipto; Chen, Xian; Chrast, Jacqueline; Curado, Joao; Derrien, Thomas; Drenkow, Jorg; Dumais, Erica; Dumais, Jacqueline; Duttagupta, Radha; Falconnet, Emilie; Fastuca, Meagan; Fejes-Toth, Kata; Ferreira, Pedro; Foissac, Sylvain; Fullwood, Melissa J.; Gao, Hui; Gonzalez, David; Gordon, Assaf; Gunawardena, Harsha; Howald, Cedric; Jha, Sonali; Johnson, Rory; Kapranov, Philipp; King, Brandon; Kingswood, Colin; Luo, Oscar J.; Park, Eddie; Persaud, Kimberly; Preall, Jonathan B.; Ribeca, Paolo; Risk, Brian; Robyr, Daniel; Sammeth, Michael; Schaffer, Lorian; See, Lei-Hoon; Shahab, Atif; Skancke, Jorgen; Suzuki, Ana Maria; Takahashi, Hazuki; Tilgner, Hagen; Trout, Diane; Walters, Nathalie; Wang, Huaien; Wrobel, John; Yu, Yanbao; Ruan, Xiaoan; Hayashizaki, Yoshihide; Harrow, Jennifer; Gerstein, Mark; Hubbard, Tim; Reymond, Alexandre; Antonarakis, Stylianos E.; Hannon, Gregory; Giddings, Morgan C.; Ruan, Yijun; Wold, Barbara; Carninci, Piero; Guigo, Roderic; Gingeras, Thomas R.
      Nature (London, United Kingdom) (2012), 489 (7414), 101-108CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836. (Nature Publishing Group)
      A review. Eukaryotic cells make many types of primary and processed RNAs that are found either in specific subcellular compartments or throughout the cells. A complete catalog of these RNAs is not yet available and their characteristic subcellular localizations are also poorly understood. Because RNA represents the direct output of the genetic information encoded by genomes and a significant proportion of a cell's regulatory capabilities are focused on its synthesis, processing, transport, modification and translation, the generation of such a catalog is crucial for understanding genome function. Here we report evidence that three-quarters of the human genome is capable of being transcribed, as well as observations about the range and levels of expression, localization, processing fates, regulatory regions and modifications of almost all currently annotated and thousands of previously unannotated RNAs. These observations, taken together, prompt a redefinition of the concept of a gene.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XhtlGnt73M&md5=8f8ee2a1189ced1010dec5e45a305acf
    14. 14
      Walder, R.; Patten, W. J. V.; Ritchie, D. B.; Montange, R. K.; Miller, T. W.; Woodside, M. T.; Perkins, T. T. High-Precision single-molecule characterization of the folding of an HIV RNA hairpin by atomic force microscopy. Nano Lett. 2018, 18, 6318– 6325,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.nanolett.8b02597
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      14
      High-Precision Single-Molecule Characterization of the Folding of an HIV RNA Hairpin by Atomic Force Microscopy
      Walder, Robert; Van Patten, William J.; Ritchie, Dustin B.; Montange, Rebecca K.; Miller, Ty W.; Woodside, Michael T.; Perkins, Thomas T.
      Nano Letters (2018), 18 (10), 6318-6325CODEN: NALEFD; ISSN:1530-6984. (American Chemical Society)
      The folding of RNA into a wide range of structures is essential for its diverse biol. functions from enzymic catalysis to ligand binding and gene regulation. The unfolding and refolding of individual RNA mols. can be probed by single-mol. force spectroscopy (SMFS), enabling detailed characterization of the conformational dynamics of the mol. as well as the free-energy landscape underlying folding. Historically, high-precision SMFS studies of RNA have been limited to custom-built optical traps. Although com. at. force microscopes (AFMs) are widely deployed and offer significant advantages in ease-of-use over custom-built optical traps, traditional AFM-based SMFS lacks the sensitivity and stability to characterize individual RNA mols. precisely. Here, the authors developed a high-precision SMFS assay to study RNA folding using a com. AFM and applied it to characterize a small RNA hairpin from HIV that plays a key role in stimulating programmed ribosomal frameshifting. The authors achieved rapid data acquisition in a dynamic assay, unfolding and then refolding the same individual hairpin more than 1100 times in 15 min. In comparison to measurements using optical traps, the AFM-based assay featured a stiffer force probe and a less compliant construct, providing a complementary measurement regime that dramatically accelerated equil. folding dynamics. Not only did kinetic anal. of equil. trajectories of the HIV RNA hairpin yield the traditional parameters used to characterize folding by SMFS (zero-force rate consts. and distances to the transition state), but the authors also reconstructed the full 1D projection of the folding free-energy landscape comparable to state-of-the-art studies using dual-beam optical traps, a first for this RNA hairpin and AFM studies of nucleic acids in general. Looking forward, the authors anticipate that the ease-of-use of the high-precision assay implemented on a com. AFM will accelerate studying folding of diverse nucleic acid structures.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXhslGqsLvE&md5=8bf17b525c2a9c52d4489737dfa3004b
    15. 15
      Sztuba-Solinska, J.; Chavez-Calvillo, G.; Cline, S. E. Unveiling the druggable RNA targets and small molecule therapeutics. Bioorg. Med. Chem. 2019, 27, 2149– 2165,  DOI: 10.1016/j.bmc.2019.03.057
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      15
      Unveiling the druggable RNA targets and small molecule therapeutics
      Sztuba-Solinska, Joanna; Chavez-Calvillo, Gabriela; Cline, Sabrina Elizabeth
      Bioorganic & Medicinal Chemistry (2019), 27 (10), 2149-2165CODEN: BMECEP; ISSN:0968-0896. (Elsevier B.V.)
      A review. The increasing appreciation for the crucial roles of RNAs in infectious and non-infectious human diseases makes them attractive therapeutic targets. Coding and non-coding RNAs frequently fold into complex conformations which, if effectively targeted, offer opportunities to therapeutically modulate numerous cellular processes, including those linked to undruggable protein targets. Despite the considerable skepticism as to whether RNAs can be targeted with small mol. therapeutics, overwhelming evidence suggests the challenges we are currently facing are not outside the realm of possibility. In this review, we highlight the most recent advances in mol. techniques that have sparked a revolution in understanding the RNA structure-to-function relationship. We bring attention to the application of these modern techniques to identify druggable RNA targets and to assess small mol. binding specificity. Finally, we discuss novel screening methodologies that support RNA drug discovery and present examples of therapeutically valuable RNA targets.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXntFCiu74%253D&md5=5c2197acf2f0a04f6fda7711fb3cc0a9
    16. 16
      Kligun, E.; Mandel-Gutfreund, Y. Conformational readout of RNA by small ligands. RNA Biol. 2013, 10, 981– 989,  DOI: 10.4161/rna.24682
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      16
      Conformational readout of RNA by small ligands
      Kligun, Efrat; Mandel-Gutfreund, Yael
      RNA Biology (2013), 10 (6), 981-989CODEN: RBNIBE; ISSN:1547-6286. (Landes Bioscience)
      RNA mols. have highly versatile structures that can fold into myriad conformations, providing many potential pockets for binding small mols. The increasing no. of available RNA structures, in complex with proteins, small ligands and in free form, enables the design of new therapeutically useful RNA-binding ligands. Here we studied RNA ligand complexes from 10 RNA groups extd. from the protein data bank (PDB), including adaptive and non-adaptive complexes. We analyzed the chem., phys., structural and conformational properties of binding pockets around the ligand. Comparing the properties of ligand-binding pockets to the properties of computed pockets extd. from all available RNA structures and RNA-protein interfaces, revealed that ligand-binding pockets, mainly the adaptive pockets, are characterized by unique properties, specifically enriched in rare conformations of the nucleobase and the sugar pucker. Further, we demonstrate that nucleotides possessing the rare conformations are preferentially involved in direct interactions with the ligand. Overall, based on our comprehensive anal. of RNA-ligand complexes, we suggest that the unique conformations adopted by RNA nucleotides play an important role in RNA recognition by small ligands. We term the recognition of a binding site by a ligand via the unique RNA conformations "RNA conformational readout.". We propose that "conformational readout" is a general way by which RNA binding pockets are recognized and selected from an ensemble of different RNA states.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXjsVWl&md5=0e6063ef9c5e97a55113b478dedd099b
    17. 17
      Kondo, J.; Westhof, E. Base pairs and pseudo pairs observed in RNA-ligand complexes. J. Mol. Recognit. 2009, 23, 241– 252,  DOI: 10.1002/jmr.978
      [Crossref], Google Scholar

      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      18
      Using Genome Sequence to Enable the Design of Medicines and Chemical Probes
      Angelbello, Alicia J.; Chen, Jonathan L.; Childs-Disney, Jessica L.; Zhang, Peiyuan; Wang, Zi-Fu; Disney, Matthew D.
      Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States) (2018), 118 (4), 1599-1663CODEN: CHREAY; ISSN:0009-2665. (American Chemical Society)
      A review. Rapid progress in genome sequencing technol. has put us firmly into a postgenomic era. A key challenge in biomedical research is harnessing genome sequence to fulfill the promise of personalized medicine. This Review describes how genome sequencing has enabled the identification of disease-causing biomols. and how these data have been converted into chem. probes of function, preclin. lead modalities, and ultimately U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA)-approved drugs. In particular, the authors focus on the use of oligonucleotide-based modalities to target disease-causing RNAs; small mols. that target DNA, RNA, or protein; the rational repurposing of known therapeutic modalities; and the advantages of pharmacogenetics. Lastly, the authors discuss the remaining challenges and opportunities in the direct utilization of genome sequence to enable design of medicines.

      19
      Synthetic small-molecule RNA ligands: future prospects as therapeutic agents
      Di Giorgio, A.; Duca, M.
      MedChemComm (2019), 10 (8), 1242-1255CODEN: MCCEAY; ISSN:2040-2503. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      RNA is one of the most intriguing and promising biol. targets for the discovery of innovative drugs in many pathologies and various biol. relevant RNAs that could serve as drug targets have already been identified. Among the most important ones, one can mention prokaryotic rRNA which is the target of several marketed antibiotics, viral RNAs or oncogenic microRNAs that are tightly involved in the development and progression of various cancers. Oligonucleotides are efficient and specific RNA targeting agents but suffer from poor pharmacodynamic and pharmacokinetic properties. For this reason, a no. of synthetic small-mol. ligands have been identified and studied upon screening of chem. libraries or focused design of RNA binders. In this review, we report the most relevant examples of synthetic compds. bearing sufficient selectivity to envisage clin. studies and future therapeutic applications with a particular attention for the main strategies that can be undertaken toward the improvement of selectivity and biol. activity.

      Connelly, C. M.; Moon, M. H.; Schneekloth, J. S. The emerging role of RNA as a therapeutic target for small molecules. Cell Chem. Biol. 2016, 23, 1077– 1090,  DOI: 10.1016/j.chembiol.2016.05.021

      20
      The Emerging Role of RNA as a Therapeutic Target for Small Molecules
      Connelly, Colleen M.; Moon, Michelle H.; Schneekloth, John S., Jr.
      Cell Chemical Biology (2016), 23 (9), 1077-1090CODEN: CCBEBM; ISSN:2451-9448. (Cell Press)
      Recent advances in understanding different RNAs and unique features of their biol. have revealed a wealth of information. However, approaches to identify small mols. that target these newly discovered regulatory elements have been lacking. The application of new biochem. screening and design-based technologies, coupled with a resurgence of interest in phenotypic screening, has resulted in several compelling successes in targeting RNA. A no. of recent advances suggest that achieving the long-standing goal of developing drug-like, biol. active small mols. that target RNA is possible. This review highlights advances and successes in approaches to targeting RNA with diverse small mols., and the potential for these technologies to pave the way to new types of RNA-targeted therapeutics.

      Strategies for the design of RNA-binding small molecules
      Aboul-Ela, Fareed
      Future Medicinal Chemistry (2010), 2 (1), 93-119CODEN: FMCUA7; ISSN:1756-8919. (Future Science Ltd.)
      A review. Bacterial rRNA is the target of clin. important antibiotics, while biol. important RNAs in viral and eukaryotic genomes present a range of potential drug targets. The physicochem. properties of RNA present difficulties for medicinal chem., particularly when oral availability is needed. Peptidic ligands and anal. of their RNA-binding properties are providing insight into RNA recognition. RNA-binding ligands include far more chem. classes than just aminoglycosides. Chem. functionalities from known RNA-binding small mols. are being exploited in fragment- and ligand-based projects. While targeting of RNA for drug design is very challenging, continuing advances in our understanding of the principles of RNA-ligand interaction will be necessary to realize the full potential of this class of targets.

      Costales, M. G.; Childs-Disney, J. L.; Haniff, H. S.; Disney, M. D. How we think about targeting RNA with small molecules. J. Med. Chem. 2020, 63, 8880– 8900,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.jmedchem.9b01927
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      22
      How We Think about Targeting RNA with Small Molecules
      Costales, Matthew G.; Childs-Disney, Jessica L.; Haniff, Hafeez S.; Disney, Matthew D.
      Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2020), 63 (17), 8880-8900CODEN: JMCMAR; ISSN:0022-2623. (American Chemical Society)
      A review. RNA offers nearly unlimited potential as a target for small mol. chem. probes and lead medicines. Many RNAs fold into structures that can be selectively targeted with small mols. This Perspective discusses mol. recognition of RNA by small mols. and highlights key enabling technologies and properties of bioactive interactions. Sequence-based design of ligands targeting RNA has established rules for affecting RNA targets and provided a potentially general platform for the discovery of bioactive small mols. The RNA targets that contain preferred small mol. binding sites can be identified from sequence, allowing identification of off-targets and prediction of bioactive interactions by nature of ligand recognition of functional sites. Small mol. targeted degrdn. of RNA targets (RNase-targeted chimeras, RIBOTACs) and direct cleavage by small mols. have also been developed. These growing technologies suggest that the time is right to provide small mol. chem. probes to target functionally relevant RNAs throughout the human transcriptome.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BB3cXlsFygsr8%253D&md5=4fe34106689d2d6d38814d79357ebd1a
    23. 23
      Ursu, A.; Childs-Disney, J. L.; Andrews, R. J.; O’Leary, C. A.; Meyer, S. M.; Angelbello, A. J.; Moss, W. N.; Disney, M. D. Design of small molecules targeting RNA structure from sequence. Chem. Soc. Rev. 2020, 49, 7252– 7270,  DOI: 10.1039/D0CS00455C
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      23
      Design of small molecules targeting RNA structure from sequence
      Ursu, Andrei; Childs-Disney, Jessica L.; Andrews, Ryan J.; O'Leary, Collin A.; Meyer, Samantha M.; Angelbello, Alicia J.; Moss, Walter N.; Disney, Matthew D.
      Chemical Society Reviews (2020), 49 (20), 7252-7270CODEN: CSRVBR; ISSN:0306-0012. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      A review. The design and discovery of small mol. medicines has largely been focused on a small no. of druggable protein families. A new paradigm is emerging, however, in which small mols. exert a biol. effect by interacting with RNA, both to study human disease biol. and provide lead therapeutic modalities. Due to this potential for expanding target pipelines and treating a larger no. of human diseases, robust platforms for the rational design and optimization of small mols. interacting with RNAs (SMIRNAs) are in high demand. This review highlights three major pillars in this area. First, the transcriptome-wide identification and validation of structured RNA elements, or motifs, within disease-causing RNAs directly from sequence is presented. Second, we provide an overview of high-throughput screening approaches to identify SMIRNAs as well as discuss the lead identification strategy, Inforna, which decodes the three-dimensional (3D) conformation of RNA motifs with small mol. binding partners, directly from sequence. An emphasis is placed on target validation methods to study the causality between modulating the RNA motif in vitro and the phenotypic outcome in cells. Third, emergent modalities that convert occupancy-driven mode of action SMIRNAs into event-driven small mol. chem. probes, such as RNA cleavers and degraders, are presented. Finally, the future of the small mol. RNA therapeutics field is discussed, as well as hurdles to overcome to develop potent and selective RNA-centric chem. probes.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BB3cXhvVClur7M&md5=9823258172b4a8392c49c5da87a23ae6

      Falese, J. P.; Donlic, A.; Hargrove, A. E. Targeting RNA with small molecules: from fundamental principles towards the clinic. Chem. Soc. Rev. 2021, 50, 2224– 2243,  DOI: 10.1039/D0CS01261K
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      24
      Targeting RNA with small molecules: from fundamental principles towards the clinic
      Falese, James P.; Donlic, Anita; Hargrove, Amanda E.
      Chemical Society Reviews (2021), 50 (4), 2224-2243CODEN: CSRVBR; ISSN:0306-0012. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      A review. Recent advances in our understanding of RNA biol. have uncovered crucial roles for RNA in multiple disease states, ranging from viral and bacterial infections to cancer and neurol. disorders. As a result, multiple labs. have become interested in developing drug-like small mols. to target RNA. However, this development comes with multiple unique challenges. For example, RNA is inherently dynamic and has limited chem. diversity. This Tutorial Review overviews important considerations and advancements for generating RNA-targeted small mols., ranging from fundamental chem. to promising small mol. examples with demonstrated clin. efficacy. We then discuss fundamental RNA recognition principles along with methods for small mol. screening and RNA structure detn. Finally, we review unique challenges and emerging solns. from both the RNA and small mol. perspectives for generating RNA-targeted ligands before highlighting a selection of the "Greatest Hits" to date. Addnl., we explore the recently FDA-approved small mol. regulator of RNA splicing, risdiplam, for treatment of spinal muscular atrophy. Together, this Tutorial Review showcases the fundamental role of chem. and mol. recognition principles in enhancing our understanding of RNA biol. and contributing to the rapidly growing no. of RNA-targeted probes and therapeutics. In particular, we hope this widely accessible review will serve as inspiration for aspiring small mol. and/or RNA researchers.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      25
      Diversifying microRNA sequence and function
      Ameres, Stefan L.; Zamore, Phillip D.
      Nature Reviews Molecular Cell Biology (2013), 14 (8), 475-488CODEN: NRMCBP; ISSN:1471-0072. (Nature Publishing Group)
      A review. MicroRNAs (miRNAs) regulate the expression of most genes in animals, but we are only now beginning to understand how they are generated, assembled into functional complexes and destroyed. Various mechanisms have now been identified that regulate miRNA stability and that diversify miRNA sequences to create distinct isoforms. The prodn. of different isoforms of individual miRNAs in specific cells and tissues may have broader implications for miRNA-mediated gene expression control. Rigorously testing the many discrepant models for how miRNAs function using quant. biochem. measurements made in vivo and in vitro remains a major challenge for the future.

      MicroRNAs: Genomics, biogenesis, mechanism, and function
      Bartel, David P.
      Cell (Cambridge, MA, United States) (2004), 116 (2), 281-297CODEN: CELLB5; ISSN:0092-8674. (Cell Press)
      A review. MicroRNAs (miRNAs) are endogenous ∼22 nt RNAs that can play important regulatory roles in animals and plants by targeting mRNAs for cleavage or translational repression. Although they escaped notice until relatively recently, miRNAs comprise one of the more abundant classes of gene regulatory mols. in multicellular organisms and likely influence the output of many protein-coding genes.

      A microRNA expression signature of human solid tumors defines cancer gene targets
      Volinia, Stefano; Calin, George A.; Liu, Chang-Gong; Ambs, Stefan; Cimmino, Amelia; Petrocca, Fabio; Visone, Rosa; Iorio, Marilena; Roldo, Claudia; Ferracin, Manuela; Prueitt, Robyn L.; Yanaihara, Nozumu; Lanza, Giovanni; Scarpa, Aldo; Vecchione, Andrea; Negrini, Massimo; Harris, Curtis C.; Croce, Carlo M.
      Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America (2006), 103 (7), 2257-2261CODEN: PNASA6; ISSN:0027-8424. (National Academy of Sciences)
      Small noncoding microRNAs (miRNAs) can contribute to cancer development and progression and are differentially expressed in normal tissues and cancers. From a large-scale miRnome anal. on 540 samples including lung, breast, stomach, prostate, colon, and pancreatic tumors, we identified a solid cancer miRNA signature composed by a large portion of overexpressed miRNAs. Among these miRNAs are some with well characterized cancer assocn., such as miR-17-5p, miR-20a, miR-21, miR-92, miR-106a, and miR-155. The predicted targets for the differentially expressed miRNAs are significantly enriched for protein-coding tumor suppressors and oncogenes (P < 0.0001). A no. of the predicted targets, including the tumor suppressors RB1 (Retinoblastoma 1) and TGFBR2 (transforming growth factor, beta receptor II) genes were confirmed exptl. Our results indicate that miRNAs are extensively involved in cancer pathogenesis of solid tumors and support their function as either dominant or recessive cancer genes.

      Stenvang, J.; Petri, A.; Lindow, M.; Obad, S.; Kauppinen, S. Inhibition of microRNA function by antimiR oligonucleotides. Silence 2012, 3, 1,  DOI: 10.1186/1758-907X-3-1

      Inhibition of microRNA function by antimiR oligonucleotides
      Stenvang, Jan; Petri, Andreas; Lindow, Morten; Obad, Susanna; Kauppinen, Sakari
      Silence (2012), 3 (), 1CODEN: SILEBI; ISSN:1758-907X. (BioMed Central Ltd.)
      A review. MicroRNAs (miRNAs) have emerged as important post-transcriptional regulators of gene expression in many developmental and cellular processes. Moreover, there is now ample evidence that perturbations in the levels of individual or entire families of miRNAs are strongly assocd. with the pathogenesis of a wide range of human diseases. Indeed, disease-assocd. miRNAs represent a new class of targets for the development of miRNA-based therapeutic modalities, which may yield patient benefits unobtainable by other therapeutic approaches. The recent explosion in miRNA research has accelerated the development of several computational and exptl. approaches for probing miRNA functions in cell culture and in vivo. In this review, we focus on the use of antisense oligonucleotides (antimiRs) in miRNA inhibition for loss-of-function studies. We provide an overview of the currently employed antisense chemistries and their utility in designing antimiR oligonucleotides. Furthermore, we describe the most commonly used in vivo delivery strategies and discuss different approaches for assessment of miRNA inhibition and potential off-target effects. Finally, we summarize recent progress in antimiR mediated pharmacol. inhibition of disease-assocd. miRNAs, which shows great promise in the development of novel miRNA-based therapeutics.

      Juliano, R. L.; Ming, X.; Nakagawa, O. The chemistry and biology of oligonucleotide conjugates. Acc. Chem. Res. 2012, 45, 1067– 1076,  DOI: 10.1021/ar2002123
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      29
      The Chemistry and Biology of Oligonucleotide Conjugates
      Juliano, R. L.; Ming, Xin; Nakagawa, Osamu
      Accounts of Chemical Research (2012), 45 (7), 1067-1076CODEN: ACHRE4; ISSN:0001-4842. (American Chemical Society)
      A review. Short DNA or RNA oligonucleotides have tremendous potential as therapeutic agents. Because of their ability to engage in Watson-Crick base pairing, they can interact with mRNA or pre-mRNA targets with high selectivity. As a result, they could precisely manipulate gene expression. This possibility has engendered extensive efforts to develop oligonucleotides as drugs, and many candidates are already in clin. trials. However, a major impediment to the maturation of this field of oligonucleotide-based therapeutics remains: these relatively large and often highly charged mols. don't easily cross cellular membranes, making it difficult for them to reach their sites of action in the cytosol or nucleus. In this Account, we summarize some basic features of the biol. of antisense and siRNA oligonucleotides. We then discuss chem. conjugation as an approach to improving the intracellular delivery and therapeutic potential of these agents. Instead of focusing on the details of conjugation chem., we emphasize the pharmacol. ramifications of oligonucleotide conjugates. In one important approach to improving delivery and efficacy, researchers have conjugated oligonucleotides with ligands designed to bind to particular receptors and thus provide specific interactions with cells. In another strategy, researchers have coupled antisense or siRNA with agents such as cell penetrating peptides that are designed to provoke escape of the conjugate from intracellular vesicular compartments. Although both of these strategies have had some success, further research is needed before oligonucleotide conjugates can find an important place in human therapeutics.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XislSqu7s%253D&md5=e6eecf9a41ee6c31acbe1018eb655d56
    30. 30
      Connelly, C. M.; Boer, R. E.; Moon, M. H.; Gareiss, P.; Schneekloth, J. S. Discovery of inhibitors of microRNA-21 processing using small molecule microarrays. ACS Chem. Biol. 2017, 12, 435– 443,  DOI: 10.1021/acschembio.6b00945
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      30
      Discovery of Inhibitors of MicroRNA-21 Processing Using Small Molecule Microarrays
      Connelly, Colleen M.; Boer, Robert E.; Moon, Michelle H.; Gareiss, Peter; Schneekloth, John S.
      ACS Chemical Biology (2017), 12 (2), 435-443CODEN: ACBCCT; ISSN:1554-8929. (American Chemical Society)
      The identification of small mols. that bind to and perturb the function of microRNAs is an attractive approach for the treatment for microRNA-assocd. pathologies. However, there are only a few small mols. known to interact directly with microRNAs. Here, the authors report the use of a small mol. microarray (SMM) screening approach to identify low mol. wt. compds. that directly bind to a pre-miR-21 hairpin. Compds. identified using this approach exhibit good affinity for the RNA (ranging from 0.8-2.0 μM) and are not composed of a polycationic scaffold. Several of the highest affinity compds. inhibit Dicer-mediated processing, while in-line probing expts. indicate that the compds. bind to the apical loop of the hairpin, proximal to the Dicer site. This work provides evidence that small mols. can be developed to bind directly to and inhibit miR-21.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XitVKqtbjP&md5=56a3a74254fc26302496b05de395591a

      Shen, H.; Zhu, F.; Liu, J.; Xu, T.; Pei, D.; Wang, R.; Qian, Y.; Li, Q.; Wang, L.; Shi, Z.; Zheng, J.; Chen, Q.; Jiang, B.; Shu, Y. Alteration in miR-21/PTEN expression modulates gefitinib resistance in non-small cell lung cancer. PLoS One 2014, 9, e103305  DOI: 10.1371/journal.pone.0103305
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      31
      Alteration in miR-21/Pten expression modulates gefitinib resistance in non-small cell lung cancer
      Shen, Hua; Zhu, Fang; Liu, Jinyuan; Xu, Tongpeng; Pei, Dong; Wang, Rong; Qian, Yingying; Li, Qi; Wang, Lin; Shi, Zhumei; Zheng, Jitai; Chen, Qiudan; Jiang, Binghua; Shu, Yongqian
      PLoS One (2014), 9 (7), e103305/1-e103305/9, 9 pp.CODEN: POLNCL; ISSN:1932-6203. (Public Library of Science)
      Resistance to TKI treatment is a major obstacle in effective treatment of NSCLC. Besides EGFR mutation status, the mechanisms involved are largely unknown. Some evidence supports a role for microRNA 21 in modulating drug sensitivity of chemotherapy but its role in NSCLC TKI resistance still remains unexplored. This study aimed to investigate whether NSCLC miR-21 mediated resistance to TKIs also results from Pten targeting. Here, we show miR-21 promotes cancer by neg. regulating Pten expression in human NSCLC tissues: high miR-21 expression levels were assocd. with shorter DFS in 47 NSCLC patients; high miR-21/low Pten expression levels indicated a poor TKI clin. response and shorter overall survival in another 46 NSCLC patients undergoing TKI treatment. In vitro assays showed that miR-21 was up-regulated concomitantly to down-regulation of Pten in pc-9/GR cells in comparison with pc-9 cells. Moreover, over-expression of miR-21 significantly decreased gefitinib sensitivity by down-regulating Pten expression and activating Akt and ERK pathways in pc-9 cells, while miR-21 knockdown dramatically restored gefitinib sensitivity of pc-9/GR cells by up-regulation of Pten expression and inactivation of AKT and ERK pathways, in vivo and in vitro. We propose alteration of miR-21/Pten expression as a novel mechanism for TKI resistance in NSCLC cancer. Our findings provide a new basis for using miR 21/Pten-based therapeutic strategies to reverse gefitinib resistance in NSCLC.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXhs1ersrnM&md5=08dda1c3b5dcd0f5ab28777438ea6533
    32. 32
      Li, Y.; Zhu, X.; Gu, J.; Hu, H.; Dong, D.; Yao, J.; Lin, C.; Fei, J. Anti-miR-21 oligonucleotide enhances chemosensitivity of leukemic HL60 cells to arabinosylcytosine by inducing apoptosis. Hematology 2010, 15, 215– 221,  DOI: 10.1179/102453310X12647083620840
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      32
      Anti-miR-21 oligonucleotide enhances chemosensitivity of leukemic HL60 cells to arabinosylcytosine by inducing apoptosis
      Li, Yumin; Zhu, Xuejiao; Gu, Jingyi; Hu, Haiyan; Dong, Dawei; Yao, Junlin; Lin, Chunyan; Fei, Jia
      Hematology (Leeds, United Kingdom) (2010), 15 (4), 215-221CODEN: HMATFL; ISSN:1024-5332. (Maney Publishing)
      Drug insensitivity or resistance is a major obstacle for successful treatment of acute myeloid leukemia. MicroRNAs (miRNAs) are small non-coding RNA mols. Increasing evidence suggests that miRNAs modulate cellular sensitivity to anticancer drugs. We used a specific anti-miR-21 oligonucleotide (AMO-miR-21) to sensitize leukemic HL60 cells to arabinosylcytosine (Ara-C) by down-regulating miR-21. AMO-miR-21 alone effectively inhibited HL60 cell viability as measured by MTT assays and induced apoptosis as evaluated by flow cytometry, whereas AMO-miR-21 in combination with Ara-C enhanced HL60 cells to Ara-C-sensitivity and promoted Ara-C-induced apoptosis. Levels of miR-21 and its target PDCD4, quantified by real-time PCR, showed that expression of miR-21 was significantly decreased after AMO-miR-21 treatment. PDCD4 as a direct target of miR-21 in leukemic HL60 cells was confirmed by the dual-luciferase reporter assay. Our study suggests that AMO-miR-21 significantly sensitizes HL60 cells to Ara-C by inducing apoptosis and these effects of AMO-miR-21 may be partially due to its up-regulation of PDCD4. Therefore, exploiting synergistic effects between AMO-miR-21 and Ara-C might be an effective clin. strategy for leukemia chemotherapy.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXhtFajsbbL&md5=89dc5e475cf062dc95a84f7a93362ed2

      Small-molecule inhibitors of microRNA miR-21 function

      Short, but significant, microRNAs (miRNAs) are an important class of gene regulators. Small-mol. modifiers of miRNA function, such as 1 (schematic representation), were identified in a cellular screen for miRNA-pathway inhibitors. Such compds. are expected to be useful tools for the elucidation of detailed mechanisms of miRNA action and may serve as lead structures for the development of new therapeutic agents.

      Jiang, C. S.; Wang, X. M.; Zhang, S. Q.; Meng, L. S.; Zhu, W. H.; Xu, J.; Lu, S. M. Discovery of 4-benzoylamino-N-(prop-2-yn-1-yl)benzamides as novel microRNA-21 inhibitors. Bioorg. Med. Chem. 2015, 23, 6510– 6519,  DOI: 10.1016/j.bmc.2015.08.007

      Discovery of 4-benzoylamino-N-(prop-2-yn-1-yl)benzamides as novel microRNA-21 inhibitors
      Jiang, Cong-shan; Wang, Xiao-meng; Zhang, San-qi; Meng, Lie-su; Zhu, Wen-hua; Xu, Jing; Lu, She-min
      Bioorganic & Medicinal Chemistry (2015), 23 (19), 6510-6519CODEN: BMECEP; ISSN:0968-0896. (Elsevier B.V.)
      MicroRNA-21, as an oncogenic miRNA, has caught great attention for medicinal chemists to develop its novel inhibitors for cancer therapy. In the present study, the authors designed 4-benzoylamino-N-(prop-2-yn-1-yl)benzamides as miR-21 inhibitor candidates on the basis of scaffold hopping. Eighteen compds. were synthesized. The inhibitory activities of synthesized compds. against the expression of miR-21 were evaluated using stem loop RT-qPCR and compd. I was discovered as the most potent compd., which displayed a time and concn. dependent inhibition manner. In addn., various functional assays such as the expression of miR-21 target gene detected by Western blotting and the cell growth and apoptosis detected by flow cytometric anal. were checked in Hela (human epithelioid cervix carcinoma) and U-87 MG (human glioblastoma) cells to confirm its activity. The results indicate that compd. I can enhance apoptosis, retard proliferation, and up-regulate PDCD4, a target protein of miR-21. In addn., the compd. I does not influence the expression of multiple miRNAs and the genes that participate in miRNA universal biosynthesis pathway. These results strongly support the assumption that title compds. can serve as a small mol. inhibitor of miR-21.

      Small Molecule Inhibition of MicroRNA miR-21 Rescues Chemosensitivity of Renal-Cell Carcinoma to Topotecan
      Naro, Yuta; Ankenbruck, Nicholas; Thomas, Meryl; Tivon, Yaniv; Connelly, Colleen M.; Gardner, Laura; Deiters, Alexander
      Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2018), 61 (14), 5900-5909CODEN: JMCMAR; ISSN:0022-2623. (American Chemical Society)
      Chem. probes of microRNA (miRNA) function are potential tools for understanding miRNA biol. that also provide new approaches for discovering therapeutics for miRNA-assocd. diseases. MicroRNA-21 (miR-21) is an oncogenic miRNA that is overexpressed in most cancers and has been strongly assocd. with driving chemoresistance in cancers such as renal cell carcinoma (RCC). Using a cell-based luciferase reporter assay to screen small mols., we identified a novel inhibitor of miR-21 function. Following structure-activity relationship studies, an optimized lead compd. demonstrated cytotoxicity in several cancer cell lines. In a chemoresistant-RCC cell line, inhibition of miR-21 via small mol. treatment rescued the expression of tumor-suppressor proteins and sensitized cells to topotecan-induced apoptosis. This resulted in a >10-fold improvement in topotecan activity in cell viability and clonogenic assays. Overall, this work reports a novel small mol. inhibitor for perturbing miR-21 function and demonstrates an approach to enhancing the potency of chemotherapeutics specifically for cancers derived from oncomiR addiction.

      Ankenbruck, N.; Kumbhare, R.; Naro, Y.; Thomas, M.; Gardner, L.; Emanuelson, C.; Deiters, A. Small molecule inhibition of microRNA-21 expression reduces cell viability and microtumor formation. Bioorg. Med. Chem. 2019, 27, 3735– 3743,  DOI: 10.1016/j.bmc.2019.05.044

      36
      Small molecule inhibition of microRNA-21 expression reduces cell viability and microtumor formation
      Ankenbruck, Nicholas; Kumbhare, Rohan; Naro, Yuta; Thomas, Meryl; Gardner, Laura; Emanuelson, Cole; Deiters, Alexander
      Bioorganic & Medicinal Chemistry (2019), 27 (16), 3735-3743CODEN: BMECEP; ISSN:0968-0896. (Elsevier B.V.)
      MicroRNAs (miRNAs) are short, non-coding RNA mols. estd. to regulate expression of a large no. of protein-coding genes and are implicated in a variety of biol. processes such as development, differentiation, proliferation, and cell survival. Dysregulation of miRNAs has been attributed to the onset and progression of various human diseases, including cancer. MicroRNA-21 (miR-21), one of the most established oncogenic miRNAs, is found to be upregulated in a wide range of cancers making it an attractive therapeutic target. Employment of a luciferase-based live-cell reporter assay in a high-throughput screen of >300,000 small mols. led to the discovery of a new class of ether-amide miR-21 inhibitors. Following a structure-activity relationship study, an optimized lead mol. was found to inhibit miR-21 transcription. Furthermore, the inhibitor demonstrated cytotoxicity in a cervical cancer cell line via induction of apoptosis and was capable of reducing microtumor formation in a long-term clonogenic assay. Altogether, this work reports the discovery of a new small mol. inhibitor of miR-21 and demonstrates its potential as an alternative approach in cancer therapy.

      37
      Regulating miRNA-21 Biogenesis By Bifunctional Small Molecules
      Yan, Hao; Bhattarai, Umesh; Guo, Zhi-Fo; Liang, Fu-Sen
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2017), 139 (14), 4987-4990CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      We report a new strategy to regulate microRNAs (miRNAs) biogenesis by using bifunctional small mols. that consist of a pre-miRNA binding unit connected by a linker to a Dicer inhibiting unit. In this effort, fluorescence polarization-based screening was used to identify neomycin as a pre-miR-21 binding ligand. Although neomycin cannot inhibit miR-21 maturation, linking it to the RNase inhibitor 1 forms the bifunctional conjugate 7A, which inhibits the prodn. of miR-21. We expect that this strategy will be applicable to design other mols. for miRNA regulation.

      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      38
      EMT: 2016
      Nieto, M. Angela; Huang, Ruby Yun-Ju; Jackson, Rebecca A.; Thiery, Jean Paul
      Cell (Cambridge, MA, United States) (2016), 166 (1), 21-45CODEN: CELLB5; ISSN:0092-8674. (Cell Press)
      A review. The significant parallels between cell plasticity during embryonic development and carcinoma progression have helped us understand the importance of the epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT) in human disease. Our expanding knowledge of EMT has led to a clarification of the EMT program as a set of multiple and dynamic transitional states between the epithelial and mesenchymal phenotypes, as opposed to a process involving a single binary decision. EMT and its intermediate states have recently been identified as crucial drivers of organ fibrosis and tumor progression, although there is some need for caution when interpreting its contribution to metastatic colonization. Here, we discuss the current state-of-the-art and latest findings regarding the concept of cellular plasticity and heterogeneity in EMT. We raise some of the questions pending and identify the challenges faced in this fast-moving field.
